It's easy to get hung up on Harry's apparent fascistic role model (as Pauline Kael and Roger Ebert famously have), but it's also easy to eschew such politics in favor of what the movie's selling: Eastwood's badass cop is there to set things right, by a moral code that we (as moviegoers) can root for. 8.5/10

I'm not really sure how, at my great age, this could be the very first time of seeing this film but I'm pretty certain it is. Looks very impressive in Blu-ray with magnificent opening scenes, shot from high up and far away and closing in on violent action in vivid, colourful close-up. Considering all the Italian police action films I have seen, odd that I should not have visited one of their major influences. Thinking about it Clint Eastwood is a pivotal and iconic figure, being influenced by but even more, himself influencing Italian crime and western films. This one is very tough and uncompromising and Eastwood strides through it, a man against the world, including the police officials he has to work around. Being of the early 70s the film is not as slick as one might expect today in so far as scenes crash and collide with night turning to day without a murmur. No time for niceties, its the story stupid! My only reservation, the film runs for 100 minutes, 90 would have made it more tight and we could probably have lost one of those meet ups with the major or governor. Splendid action though and again being early 70s goes out of its way to show a bit of sleaze every now and again.

The late sixties and seventies saw the growth of the "tough cop" thriller. In earlier crime thrillers ("White Heat", from the late forties, is a good example) the police had generally been portrayed as honourable and incorruptible men who did everything by the book. The new breed of heroes were different. They were not only tough but also morally ambiguous, capable of bending and even breaking the rules when they thought it was necessary.Before making "Dirty Harry", Clint Eastwood had acted in another film of this type, "Coogan's Bluff". Both films had the same director, Don Siegel. "Coogan's Bluff, however, is a lightweight film, with a rather annoying hero who likes to cut corners because he cannot be bothered to go through the proper channels. My sympathies are with Lee J. Cobb's old-school New York cop, irritated beyond measure by Coogan's impatience and cowboy brashness.In "Dirty Harry" much more important matters are at stake. A serial killer calling himself "Scorpio" is terrorising San Francisco by carrying out killings at random. Some of his victims seem to have been chosen on the basis of religious or racial bigotry, but Scorpio's main motive is blackmail; he will stop killing if the city authorities pay him $100,000. When this blackmail fails, Scorpio kidnaps a young girl, buries her underground with a limited supply of oxygen and announces that he will let her die if his demands are not met. Reluctantly, the authorities agree to hand over the money.The police officer on the case is Inspector Harry Callahan, nicknamed "Dirty Harry", partly because of his uncompromising methods and partly because he gets the jobs other officers don't want. Disgusted by the willingness of the authorities to meet Scorpio's demands, Harry tracks down the main suspect, arrests him after shooting him in the leg, finds the murder weapon and forces him to reveal the girl's whereabouts (unfortunately too late to save her life). Although there can be no doubt of the man's guilt, the city's Mayor and District Attorney order his release because the evidence against him is inadmissible; Harry had no warrant to search his premises and the confession obtained by strong-arm methods would not be admissible in Court. Scorpio's narrow escape does not, however, persuade him that crime does not pay, and soon afterwards he kidnaps and holds hostage a busload of schoolchildren. Only Harry can save them In some ways Harry is an unsympathetic character. He is cool to the point of coldness and always has an air of menace about him, particularly during the famous "Do you feel lucky?" speech. Some of his dialogue suggests that he is racially prejudiced himself. Clint Eastwood made the role so much his own that it is strange to think he was only fourth choice after Frank Sinatra, John Wayne and Paul Newman. It is doubtful whether any of those actors could have played the part so well. Sinatra might have made him too unsympathetic. Newman could have conveyed his coolness but might not have had the same underlying menace. Wayne (as he was to prove in "Brannigan" a few years later) was definitely too old for a role of this type.This film has always been controversial, with critics divided along ideological lines. (The film-makers seem to have intended a deliberate juxtaposition of Harry's values with those of the city of San Francisco which, during the hippie era, was becoming known as America's most liberal city). Liberals such as Roger Ebert have loathed Harry, seeing him as a man who thinks himself above the law, even a fascist. They note that his treatment of Scorpio violates (as the DA points out) at least three, and possibly four, constitutional amendments. (Such liberal critics are divided as to whether the film condemns or condones Harry's methods). Conservatives, however, see him as a hero, a man who will defend the public from crime while his superiors seem more concerned to defend the criminals. They point out that the seventies liberals who were so quick to condemn Harry for acting in breach of the constitution did not apply the same literal-minded legalism to, say, those who were resisting the (constitutionally permissible) Vietnam draft or to civil rights protesters who were engaged in civil disobedience against (constitutionally tolerated) racism in the Southern states."Dirty Harry" is much more than a cop thriller; it is a film that asks some important questions. It may seem odd to compare a tough cop with draft resisters or with civil rights campaigners, but Harry faces a moral choice similar to that confronting those two groups of people. In each case the central question is "If there is a conflict between the two, should one obey the law of the land or should one obey one's own conscience". This is a question to which there is often no easy answer and is particularly acute for Harry because, as a police officer, he is duty-bound to uphold the law. The law states that he should not carry out a search without a warrant and that he should not use force to obtain a confession from Scorpio. His conscience tells him that he must do both these things to save an innocent life.The German dramatist Friedrich Hebbel once remarked that tragedy does not arise out of the conflict of right and wrong. It arises out of the conflict of two rights. This is the situation which we see in this film, which means that both the liberal and conservative viewpoints quoted above are right- and both are wrong. The law is right to impose limits on police powers, in order to protect the citizen from abuse of those powers by corrupt or over-zealous officers. And Harry is right to go beyond those limits in an effort to save a life. 8/10

Review title: I was very "lucky" to watch such a great flick!
Review_body: What can you say about Dirty Harry that hasn't already been said? This is a very cool movie and without a doubt my favorite Clint Eastwood character. He is just such a cool good/bad cop, you gotta love him. Especially those famous words "You gotta ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do you, punk?". What a great line! What great deliverance as well! Dirty Harry was the movie before any famous cop flicks came out really, and it was interesting to see from a cop's point of view on the emotions that run through his head when he captures a filthy criminal and they go free. The whole movie you just root for his character and hope that good will always triumph. This is a terrific film and essential to the 70's! 8/10

Don Siegel's "Dirty Harry" was arguably the start of the serial killer/cop genre inherent in so many mainstream American movies released today. Setting the stage for countless rip-offs and sequels, "Dirty Harry" was one of the true first of its kind--not only in regards to its genre influence but also in terms of its content. (Full frontal nudity, heavy vigilante-style violence and strong language.) It is, in fact, one of the quintessential 1970s films--capturing the very essence of the typical gritty '70s film style we're all familiar with. If "Midnight Cowboy" began the trend, "Dirty Harry" extends it.Clint Eastwood delivers one of his finest performances as the titular "Dirty" Harry Callahan. He's got just the right amount of cocky cynacism and inset sense of self-justice and importance to make the character realistic and likable, despite his flaws.The plot almost seems routine now, but back in '71 it was controversial stuff: Harry is a tough cop trying to track down a mad serial killer in San Francisco, who is murdering victims in an effort to receive ransom money. When he kidnaps a young girl, Harry makes it his mission to disobey direct orders and take on the killer by himself.It's easy to point at this now and say, "I've seen this already." In many cases film classics can only be graded well for nostalgic purposes, because their imitators have improved upon the original material.Not here. The original really does still remain (one of) the best.Siegel would later follow up "Dirty Harry" with another examination of criminals and cops, and would also team up again with Clint Eastwood. This is probably his best film, which is saying a lot. Its reputation precedes it, but in this case, the strength of the film itself really is deserving of its popularity. The final speech is awesome stuff.

When this movie was released it was cutting edge stuff. As it heads for 40 years, it is now more average stuff. It fit Eastwoods fan base perfect in 1971.John Vernon would go from being Mayor of San Francisco in this to being a college president in Animal House. He always seems to be the same guy in every movie. He is the leader who is blissfully in the dark. He is that man here too.The plots have to do with establishing Harry Callahan as a no nonsense Detectvie in California to a crazy guy name Scorpio trying to kill everybody including Harry in a lunatic binge. This type of plot and action & language & nudity became standard for quite a while after this movie was made. The thing the viewer should ask them self is do they feel lucky? Once you see this one, you understand what established Eastwood enough in this role that he would do it again, and again for about 4 films. Later on in the series, he would utter "make my day" which is copied often too. The copying proves the value of this original film.

Along with The French Connection, this influential thriller set the standard for cop movies for the 70's, i.e. tough, violent, bleak and unflinching. This movie, in particular, attracted a lot of criticism that it was a fascistic celebration of police brutality. And while it's hard to argue against this, Dirty Harry is an extremely well-made thriller that is still sufficiently edgy and energetic to appeal to modern audiences.It's about a renegade cop called Harry Callaghan who is on a mission to stop – by any means possible – a psychotic killer-hippy who is holding San Francisco to ransom. Clint Eastwood is perfectly cast in the lead role. This, along with his Man With No Name roles in Sergio Leone's Dollars Trilogy, is his most defining and iconic screen performance. He is believably tough and has a great screen presence. Other standout members of the cast are Andy Robinson as the vile villain and John Vernon as the agreeably cheesy mayor. The film is helped hugely, too, by the great soundtrack by Lalo Schifrin. This funky score gives the film an energy and atmosphere that's integral to its success. It compliments both the high octane action and the suspense scenes. There's some great cinematography too, such as the beautiful pan of the San Francisco Bay early in the movie and the extraordinary reverse zoom that takes us from Callaghan torturing Scorpio in the sports stadium to high up in the sky; an incredible shot.This film still holds up well after all these years. It still has retained much of its edge. Don Siegel keeps everything moving along at a great pace and shows himself very adept at creating a threatening atmosphere when required. The set-piece in the park at night is almost in Italian giallo territory. Going back to the accusations of Dirty Harry appealing to a right-wing mentality and that the Scorpio character represents the ugly side of the counter-culture, deserving of no mercy from the authorities. While all this is true, it's also true that the villain is such an irredeemable scumbag that it is impossible not to back Harry Callaghan to the hilt. And at the end of the day this is a cop-thriller so no one should really be taking it THAT seriously. A much better approach is to just sit back, relax and enjoy a classic hard, sleazy and thrilling piece of 70's cinema.

The movie Dirty Harry really is all it's cracked up to be: A damned good action-packed crime-thriller. Dirty Harry (Clint Eastwood) is out to get the notorious and crazed Scorpio-killer Andy Robinson (Andrew Robinson). It is a film worth watching if you like crime-thrillers with some action.Some critics are not fond of Andy Robinson as the Scorpio-killer but I have to completely disagree. I think Robinson was perfect for the role. With Andrew playing the role, we have a killer (Andy) with an innocent look about him - and that alone is enough to believe him blameless of such gruesome crimes - but behind his looks is a mind of a criminally sick man. Outstanding performance by Andrew Robinson.Clint Eastwood - he is just as good as always. He is a well seasoned, brilliant actor.8.5/10

Review title: the one that started it all
Review_body: while i did like this first film in the Dirty Harry series for the most part,there were a few things about it that didn't work for me.one thing was i thought it was a bit slow in spots,not enough to make a huge difference in quality,just enough to notice.also the story***possible minor spoiler.i think it was based(loosely)on the real life Zodiac killings***end of spoiler.it just seemed a bit ordinary to me.it didn't have any gravitas or oomph to it.the acting was good all around,although i have to single out Andy Robinson who was superb as the villain.overall,despite a few minor problems,this is still a very good film,with many more positive aspects than negatives.for me,Dirty Harry is a 7/10

Review title: The beginning of a classic 70's series
Review_body: This movie is the epitome of what 70's movie was at least for this type, and has many good aspect to it. This movie may come off a bit cliché but it has certain elements that make it really stand out, plus it's a movie from the 70's. Not just that this was somewhat the pioneer when it comes to cop versus serial killer style scenario, well at least the direction of it all. This movie is about Harry Callahan played by Clint Eastwood who is a badass inspector that gets into some police action while trying to track down the main villain who kills innocent people with a sniper rifle. This movie is constant but steady cop action movie. Sure some parts the cops seem overly incompetent at times and the villain sometimes comes off really ridiculous although vile. But it doesn't go way too over the top, overall this movie is a steady action/thriller that doesn't get boring. It even has classic one liners like "you gotta ask yourself one question. Do I feel lucky? Well do you punk?". Sometimes the dialogue maybe a bit silly at times but it doesn't get to the point where it gets irritating to listen to. This isn't the best movie I seen for this type of genre but for a movie that is made in the 70's it's really authentic.8/10

This is Clint Eastwood's iconic film, where he plays San Francisco police officer Harry Callahan, aka Dirty Harry. He is assigned to track and capture a murdering psychopath called the Scorpio, who has been terrorizing the city with homicides and demands thousands of dollars from the police in return for stopping his crime spree.The mystery begins immediately when the Scorpio strikes at the beginning of the film, grasping the audience's attention and leading to one suspenseful scene after the other as Dirty Harry tries to track down Scorpio. The manhunt of Scorpio and the random police action scenes like Harry taking down a band of robbers and dealing with a suicidal man keeps the plot momentum going strong.The cinematography by Bruce Surtees captures the tense atmosphere and bustling city life of San Francisco, with Dirty Harry roaming the streets like the loan wolf, looking to do justice and reminding you of a film-noir type setting. Don Siegel did a nice job directing, keeping the film interesting for the most part and leaving little room for boring fillers, which there are a few (like the uninteresting scenes with the dumb district attorney), but none too much to drag the main plot away from the audience. The acting was spot-on, particularly that of Eastwood's calm and collected demeanor, even when angry, and his deadpan delivery, and Andrew Robinson's deranged and crazy portrayal of Scorpio. The cat and mouse game between Harry and Scorpio consumes much of the film. It's a classic cop vs. madman movie that stands out well throughout the test of time.Grade B

Review title: Eastwood's Signature Role Is Still A Winner
Review_body: Clint Eastwood will always be thought of as Dirty Harry - even I, who had never before seen Dirty Harry, knew enough about the movie for instance, to be able to understand the similarities between Harry and Eastwood's character of Walt Kowalski from 2008's "Gran Torino." This is his signature role for good reason - he's perfectly cast as Inspector Harry Callahan and the movie is both exciting and interesting and has a realistic feel to it.Callahan is assigned to locate a serial killer who calls himself "Scorpio" and threatens to kill a person a day unless the city of San Francisco pays him $100,000 (later raised to $200,000.) Callahan doesn't go by the book. In his view, his job is to get the bad guys and that's what he does - except that not going by the book lets the serial killer get away, because his constitutional rights were violated. That's really the underlying theme of the movie - how do you defend the rights of the innocent victims when you have to be so concerned about the rights of the accused. That's a concern that remains with us even today, so even though the movie is almost 40 years old, it still has a relevance to it; a message which will resonate with many people. The movie leads up to a pretty exciting ending with the school bus hijacking, and Callahan's last statement of contempt for the system in which he works.If I were to compare this to, say, "Gran Torino" (Eastwood's latest and perhaps last movie) I'd say that I preferred "Gran Torino" more because there seemed to be more sustained excitement in it, whereas "Dirty Harry" (because Callahan is an active cop) has a few more mundane scenes, since it has to portray the system in which Callahan works. I still liked this, though. It's a great role for Eastwood.

(There are Spoilers) The movie "Dirty Harry" begins and ends in a body of water. As if it had to do with the primal fears of safety and survival that flow in depths of the minds of those watching the motion picture."Dirty Harry" starts off with a girl diving into a swimming pool and then being caught in the cross-hairs of the sadistic killer in the film, Scorpio, and shot dead, The movie ends with Scorpio trying to go for his gun after "Dirty Harry" Callahan had blown it out of his hand a moment before and then being blasted by Harry's 44 Magnum and falling into the river dead. In between those two scenes director Don Siegle and actor Clint Eastwood constructed a morality play about whats wrong in America circa 1971. The criminals are too safe and the law abiding public are not thank to the liberals and the laws they passed in favor of the criminal element in this country. This was in 1971 before crimes in high places by CEO's as well as elected officials became common place in the news. If "Dirty Harry" were made today it would not have any impact at all on the public like it did back in 1971 and would have flopped in the box office because the public has learned a lot since then. What the public learned is that if you take the rights away from one person, no matter how guilty he may seem to be, you take the rights away from every one of us no matter how innocent we are. In the movie Harry could do no wrong, he's right in every one of his actions, in his war against the criminal element of San Francisco. His superiors, from the mayor on down, come across as gutless cowards at best or lying hypocrites at worst and make those watching the movie wonder just how they ever got elected and kept their jobs in the first place.With the danger to the public now gone Harry, in disgust, at the end of the movie throws his badge into the river where the dead Scorpio is floating, whom he had just shot. Like Gary Cooper in "High Noon" Harry turns his back on the society that he just saved from the likes of Scorpio and walks into the sunset leaving them to fend for themselves, because they didn't accept and appreciate what he's done for them.In short the movie "Dirty Harry" was really a propaganda film for less laws and more power for those in power. It was interesting to see that in only two years, at the height of the Watergate scandal in 1973, after "Dirty Harry" was released that it's sequel "Magnum Force" had "Dirty Harry" Callahan talking like the wimps and cowards in the first "Dirty Harry" movie. Harry is now in favor of letting the law and the system do it's job. Harry's enemy in that movie is a squad of vigilante cops who were nothing but "Dirty Harry" clones led by a corrupt police official and at one point in the movie they even invited Harry to join them which of course he refused. Thats what was the difference between the original "Dirty Harry" movie and the four sequels that followed it. The first took itself seriously and the others didn't. What we learned since 1971, when "Dirty Harry" was released, was what Benjamin Franklin said over two hundred years ago: "That when one gives up his rights for peace and security he ends up having neither", and so did the film makers of the "Dirty Harry" movies.

Review title: Launching a Hollywood legend---Dirty Harry is a classic of its time
Review_body: As one of the world's biggest Clint Eastwood fans I can already foresee fellow Eastwood fans taking offense to my 'low' rating. It actually surprised me when I re-watched Dirty Harry which I hadn't seen for probably better than 10 years. It isn't that I dislike Dirty Harry whatsoever. You couldn't possibly NOT like Dirty Harry, the character and the film is legendary and I thoroughly enjoy ranting out Harry's infamous "Do you feel lucky, punk?" speech whenever I get the chance. However I also believe Dirty Harry has lost something to time. One of the things that makes Dirty Harry so legendary is the timing. Dirty Harry put a strong face to the law who didn't have the best reputation coming out of the sixties and rioting. Harry Callahan hated everyone equally...he wasn't racist, he just hated all scum of any color and wasn't afraid to pull his gun to blow that scum away if need be. Essentially Harry Callahan was the original Jack Bauer (24--Kiefer Sutherland) The film set up a deranged killer that certainly looked the psycho role and you rooted for Harry because he was determined to always do the right thing no matter what he had to do to do it.Clint Eastwood is Dirty Harry. He was Harry before Harry existed and he'll be Harry long after he's gone. Eastwood being the baddest ass dude on the planet and Harry is clearly the baddest ass cop on the planet. It's not a brilliant performance but it also has more depth than some of his earlier work, like his Westerns. It is good that they serialized the Dirty Harry films because this first movie left you wanting to know more about him. Dirty Harry launched a four decade career for actor Andrew Robinson who after seeing him play the "Scorpio" killer you'll be convinced he truly is deranged. He has few lines but what he does with his facial expressions and his eyes is just astounding. The large supporting cast includes the likes of John Vernon, John Larch, and Reni Santoni to name a few of the stronger members. The problem is they all should get more screen time and they seem like strong characters but they take a back seat.Dirty Harry could also be described as one of the great cat and mouse films of all time. Harry chasing Scorpio through various locations and situations but then that isn't the only thing happening in the film. Harry is also breaking up robberies, stopping to help citizens and busting the scum off the street. Legendary director Don Siegel takes the helm and gives it his gritty style that is a must for the film. It's almost like he takes the wild west and turns it into a modern day San Francisco. Siegal and Eastwood worked together a lot in the seventies and I'm thinking why Eastwood was likely able to create Harry Callahan exactly the way he wanted him to be. Dirty Harry is almost always classified as an "action film" but it isn't. Instead Dirty Harry is a dark drama about a cop who will stop at nothing to take a psychotic off the streets. Harry Callahan is Jack Bauer, Martin Riggs, Starsky, Hutch, Rockford, and Columbo rolled into one hero. It is a must see but don't expect it to live up to the standards of nowadays. 7/10

A new kind of cop for a new decade. With "Dirty Harry" Siegel and Eastwood created one of cinema's most enigmatic figures in Inspector Harry Callahan, a monosyllabic, no-nonsense cop, based in San Francisco, who freely uses his Magnum 357 gun like it's an extension to his right hand and is very much of the "shoot first, ask questions later" school of policing.Nicknamed "Dirty Harry" because he always gets the dirty jobs other cops won't touch, we first see him single-handedly take down a gang robbing a bank which culminates in round one of his classic "Do you feel lucky, punk?" confrontations, staring down the barrel of his gun, daring said punk to go for his nearby gun and then using a similarly unconventional "I dare you..." interview technique to talk down a potential suicide jumper. Not a by-the-book copper then, he prefers to work alone and little cares for the politicking and compromising of his bosses, who he tolerates just so long as they don't interfere with his individual modus operandum.So here's a cop with no hinterland, we never see where we lives and just about glean that his wife died in an undetermined past and that he appears to have no kids. Married to the job, he lives for the next dirty case to fall into his lap and sure enough, along comes a sniper-killer, shooting innocent people with his long-range rifle, demanding a ransom from the city mayor to stop his promised one-a-day murdering spree.Harry's pursuit of the self-named "Scorpio" killer soon becomes personal between the two of them and ebbs and flows through a tense pursuit in a football stadium then a legal stand-off which sees the killer freed and finally an inevitable reckoning between the two after Scorpio has hijacked and threatened to kill a school bus containing young children."Dirty Harry" set the bar for violent, uncompromising police thrillers and Eastwood proved the perfect medium for the iconic title role, in so doing, updating and adapting his earlier "Man with no name" characterisation from the Leone westerns to the present day. I don't think the film works completely, for one thing believing that Scorpio's character could have been built up more while some of the plotting and supporting characterisations seem somewhat haphazard and sketchy, not to mention exhibiting a little decidedly "of its time" casual racism and sexism. I'd also question having Harry recite again the "Go for your gun" ultimatum at the end as an unnecessary repetition of what was a brilliant stand-alone scene from earlier in the film, but there's no doubt with its extensive use of fluid camera-work, location photography, realistic, pared-down dialogue and explosive set-pieces, Siegel and Eastwood had happened on a dynamic template for much of what would follow in the New Hollywood of the next decade and beyond, not least a slew of its own sequels, none of which however, bettered the original.

Last time, while I was reading the news on my laptop, I was both shocked and saddened by the story of a young 17-year old girl raped and killed while jogging before her corpse would be meticulously hidden and burnt, a sordid and macabre story whose savagery unfortunately equals its daily frequency in our world. And while I was reading the Internet readers' comments, I found out that many of them, filled with the same anger than I, were demanding vengeance or asking for more ruthlessness from the authorities. And although I always try to be rational, the cruelty of the crime made me question my own approach to justice, if its blindness puts the victim and the criminal on an equal foot or if its only purpose should be to punish and repress those who banish themselves from society.That's the issue, the frontier between repression and fascism is so thin that any zealous expression of Law's repressive hand can be perceived as oppressive. This is why "Dirty" Harry Callahan was probably one of these characters that embodied so many contradictions he became one of the quintessential anti-heroic figures of American cinema, and it's no surprise that he was created during that glorious 'New Hollywood' era that tackled social issues with a rebellious attitude and total disregard for political correctness. The contradiction of "Dirty" Harry is that in the context of the 70's where urban criminality reached a high level of violence and savagery, it put the police cops in a weak position, in the public opinion's eyes, so people needed a strong model to incarnate Law and Authority. But during that same context, a new air of freedom and rebellion against the power was filling the youth's hearts, or any idealistic people that could perceive Harry as a fascist. We can say that basically, there were two sides in 1971, the Jimmy "Popeye" Doyle and the Alex De Large's side, while "Dirty" Harry has something of both.Harry Callahan is the incarnation of Law in its most Antic form, carrying his iconic Magnum .44 as the sword to fight the evildoer and the shield to protect the widow and the orphan, yet he's victim of his own hatred, and uses violence as a personal policy, with a Magnum that provides a virile magnetism, inspiring our respect despite everything. Indeed, Clint Eastwood incarnates this violence with such charisma and the perfect amount of fierceness in his eyes that it's hard not to find him appealing, and I defy any man not to have a male crush on him, seriously, I'm not ashamed to admit that he's probably the most handsome and manly character ever. And what makes him so dangerously attractive is the key element he has in common with De Large, more than Doyle : his enjoyment of ultra violence. If you look closer : he get his kicks by applying justice with his Magnum, as a phallic extension. The way he uses his 'feel lucky' catchphrase as an usual tirade that allows him to tease the criminal is the little delight, sadistic maybe, but with quite an allure.But I guess this is the danger of Dirty Harry and what earned the film so many criticisms at the time of its release when it was labeled as a "right-wing fantasy" or a film with fascist tendencies, as if it conveyed the dangerous idea that the ends justified the means, and the use of violence can be legitimate in some extreme cases. And maybe this is the manipulative aspect of the film, it features an extremely vicious criminal who kills innocent people, more innocent than usual, just for money and certainly not without pleasure. As much as we admire the performance of the actor, he's impossible to root for, as he represents the degeneration of a society with no values and morality, and the most capable hero must have the same level of cruelty as the villain. It's an eye for an eye yes, it's not very legal, but this is Harry's law. It's not fascist, it's just 'extreme'. An extreme way used in the right side of the law, and 40 years later, despite all the criticism from left-wing or feminist movements, the movie had four sequels, and Harry Callahan is one of the most iconic movie characters ever, #17 in AFI's list of heroes, for having paved the way to other classic "loose cannon" cops facing incompetent superiors like in "Die Hard" or "Lethal Weapon".The movie stood the test of time, and for a simple reason: people needed a character like "Dirty Harry" to identify with, to stop associating the law with dumb policemen or simple comic reliefs, they needed a model of power and manly integrity. The "right-wing fantasy" is half right, there is something super-heroic in Callahan, that makes the movie like a sort of fantasy, but the man is vulnerable, he takes hits, he's victim of his own prejudices and bigotry, he's got the same flaws as an Ethan Edwards or a Fred C. Dobbs, which makes his brutality, more forgivable because he's fundamentally good. He's definitely the archetypal antihero, and maybe his appeal is revealing or our own subconscious perception of violence. Something we condemn, we debate on, but which we're glad when it's being done.I started the review by evoking a news item, I will conclude with something more global by comparing Harry to those soldiers who were sent to Vietnam if we keep the movie into context, or now in Iraq, or Afghanistan to do all the dirty jobs, while the politicians were talking about freedom, justice, and democracy, all these big words without echoes in those doomed places in the world. Harry fascinates us, because he makes us think of our own hypocritical approach to violence, and our possible need of dirty Harries to clean our consciences, maybe that's the question we've got to ask ourselves.

Review title: A real, slightly revisionist grit underlies this iconic, straight-shooting detective drama.
Review_body: 'Dirty Harry (1971)' isn't quite what you'd expect from the reputation that precedes it; it's far more thematically complex than that. Clint Eastwood's squinting straight-shooter, the disillusioned detective at the heart of this dark yet entertaining tale, is a surprisingly compelling lead, much more than just the poker-faced, hand-cannon-carrying cool cucumber he's now known as. The film itself is just as concerned with its slower moments as it is with its moments of action, building a suspenseful story that explodes with the sort of violence that actually matters. It's essentially a commentary on the justice system and, whether or not you agree with its wider politics, it does a great job of getting you on its side. Ultimately, there's a real, slightly revisionist grit underlying a narrative that's got something to say and isn't afraid to say it. 8/10

Viewed almost four decades after its making 'Dirty Harry' looks a little bit like an aged action film, but it raises issues that are actual until today. The story of SF Police detective Harry Callahan specialized in the dirty jobs that nobody wants to undertake, facing a system of laws and rules which seems to favor the bad guys and not the law enforcers looks for the viewer today quite 'deja vu'. We also have seen many times the junior policeman partner becoming a key help and element in the action, and even the car scenes on San Francisco's streets. The psycho serial killer, the weak politicians ready to give up to blackmail in order to win some moments of apparent peace, all look familiar. The merit of director Siegel's film is that in 1971 he was the first to bring together all these themes and characters in one coherent and well told story, without many convolutions or ramifications.Clint Eastwood gives up here the Wild West poncho and replaces it with the elegant jacket of the 20th century policeman, but brings here from the previous films the calm, the art of handling guns and the scarcity of words which when infringed leaves room for many memorable phrases. Eastwood's character faces dilemmas similar to the one that '24''s Jack Bauer will face more than three decades later. When human lives are in balance are officers of law allowed to break rules and take the law in their hands? When the judicial system is unable to defend the victims and punish the guilty can one man take the responsibility of playing the judge and the executor? (with no less than a punishment but the deserved capital one). It's easier to answer such questions in movies than in real life. 'Dirty Harry' and many other films that followed gave to such question simplistic and problematic answers. As they say - 'do not try this at home'. At the end of the day this is still entertainment, reality is more complex.

Review title: Feels like a standard TV crime drama
Review_body: Dirty Harry hasn't aged that well, punk. Now that this type of story has been copied so many times (with certain aspects done better), this movie feels like a standard TV crime drama. Nevertheless, Andrew Robinson is a pretty terrifying villain, and Clint Eastwood plays it cool as Inspector Callahan. I look forward to seeing what the sequels have to offer.

Review title: A Well Acted Crime Film with One of Eastwoods Most Memorable Performances
Review_body: Dirty Harry is a good movie with a well developed storyline and a terrific cast. It is a very enjoyable crime film that contains both thrilling scenes and also some stellar action sequences, it has a nice mix of both and neither feel overused. The role of Harry Callahan was perfect for Clint Eastwood, it was the right character for him, gave him the chance to stretch his acting skills a lot more and break free from doing westerns, it is one of his most memorable performances and it is clear throughout that he really connected with this character. Very well acted and quite thrilling, Dirty Harry is a very enjoyable movie that I would recommend to anyone looking for a good crime film or thriller. A maverick cop attempts to bring a cold blooded serial killer to justice before he kills again.Best Performance: Clint Eastwood Worst Performance: Harry Guardino

It's somewhat ironic that Clint Eastwood would become a household name by playing "the man with no name" before transitioning away from Westerns into contemporary movies, and then the movie that made him a superstar for the second time was a larger than life character than be identified first as a classic archetype and cinema icon and as a Eastwood role second.Everybody knows Dirty Harry. The attitude, the scowl, and the one-liners have been mimicked and parodied so many times, and the original movie, and it's sequels, have spawned countless new generations of similar hardcore heroes. Without Harry Callaghan there would be no John Matrix, no Cobra, no John McClane, no Martin Riggs, etc. Is the original film itself any good? Well, it's certainly controversial, even in the present day. Though much of the film's politics seem to be projected into the movie by its audience than actually part of film itself. In reality it's a very straight-forward, laid-back affair with minimalist dialogue, editing, and a subdued style.There's not much in the way of plot, and there's very little detective work or puzzle solving on Harry's part. He's just a blunt tool used for a dirty job, hence the name. For a movie that barely nudges past the 100-minute mark it does feel a lot long, with lingering shots, huge chunks of purely visual storytelling, and a few detours that feel like padding. The central story of a crazed sniper offing random civilians in San Francisco, inspired by the real life Zodiac murder case, isn't strong enough to last the already thin running time.It is a movie that is about style over substance, and for its day it was very slick and high key with gorgeous anamorphic Panavision photography. Does it hold up? Just about. It's not a movie that I watch for the entertainment value, but merely to study how certain classics were made.

Review title: Eastwood shines as the soft-spoken but deadly serious detective Harry Callahan
Review_body: In the opening scene of the film, a beautiful young woman swims in a rooftop pool. Poor gal. A shooter (Andrew Robinson) from a nearby building kills her with one shot. Soon, the SFPD will send detective Harry Callahan to investigate the happening. As "Dirty Harry" discovers the place where the shooter did his deed, Harry finds a note. Calling himself Scorpio, the assassin insists the city pay him big bucks or he will kill again; the victim will be a priest or a black American. Pulling his hair out, the mayor decides they should pay but Harry is adamant they should NOT. A compromise posting in the SF Chronicle says they will pay but need more time. Meanwhile, Harry goes to lunch but can't even digest his food without needing to stop a bank robbery nearby! Harry is one cool cop. The top police brass give Harry a new partner named Chico (Reni Santori) but he's rather green. Nevertheless, together these two hatch plans to "catch" Scorpio without paying big money. Unhappily, Scorpio matches them with tricky escapes. Now, a school bus full of children may be in danger! What can Harry do? This gritty, somewhat violent film is taken from the story of the real Zodiac killer. Its a sick, twisted tale but Harry is one admirable detective, played to understated perfection by Eastwood. Santori is quite likeable, Robinson is great as the loathsome killer and other cast members quite fine. Add on good cinematography and a tense, inventive plot and the movie is quite compelling. Its a classic folks! Don't delay in viewing it.

Review title: "Now you know why they call me Dirty Harry: every dirty job that comes along."
Review_body: I know what you're thinking. "Did he fire six shots or only five?" Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kinda lost track myself. But being this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world and would blow your head clean off, you've gotta ask yourself one question: "Do I feel lucky?" Well, do ya, punk?A cult action thriller starring Clint Eastwood, a film that, along with Leone's trilogy, is probably the most responsible for Eastwood's fame, and from which some of the most iconic replicas in film history have originated ... bored me to death and I barely made it to the end. With all due respect for its status and objective qualities, I can't rate it above5/10

An influential cop movie that helped make Eastwood into a superstar. It has his memorable soliloquy ("I know what you're thinking punk..."). Seeing it now, however, it is not much better than an episode of a cop show on TV. The script is rather lame. The scene where Eastwood jumps on the bus from the overpass is pretty silly. What happens to the yellow bag that Eastwood carries to the killer? Robinson makes a terrifying villain yet he's also pretty funny, particularly in the scene where he has the kids sing in the bus. Director Siegel is in his element in this kind of film. This is an interesting companion piece to Bullitt, a better film made three years earlier.

Dirty Harry (1971)Plot In A Paragraph: You know the story. A sniper calling himself Scorpio is terrorising the city, picking off victims from rooftops, and demanding a huge ransom from the mayor. Inspector Callahan (Eastwood) is given the task of stopping him, but his unorthodox way of doing things quickly brings him into conflict with his superiors. For me this is Clint's biggest and best performance to date. Some may argue it's simply the Man with no name, given a name and dumped in San Francisco. But I don't see it that way. Harry is much flashier and wittier than than the man with no name.Siegel messes with usual cop thriller convention. The identity of the killer is revealed almost straight away and he is hardly the cunning criminal that cops of Harry's calibre usually have to face. Also Scorpio is a terrible serial killer!! OK... he's pretty good at killing, but it's only blind luck that stops him from getting caught by police no fewer than three times in the first 40 minutes. Harry's biggest adversary is actually the law itself, since Scorpio is captured at the film's mid-point, but our hero's disregard for due process and the killer's 'rights' see him released back into society.The legal argument represented by John Vernon's do-gooder mayor) is well presented, and even though he ultimately gets his man, Harry's catalogue of citizen endangering stunts, in particular risking the lives of a busload of kidnapped schoolkids during the climax, remain questionable at best.Whilst there had been cinematic psychopaths before, Scorpio is given no background, no real motives for his crime and he doesn't even have a real name!! Likewise, we may not find out much about Harry, we know his wife recently died, but that's really it!! but the mix of conviction and disgust with which he goes about his job say more than any number of speeches about the rights and wrongs of modern police work ever could.A 10/10 for me.Dirty Harry grossed at the domestic box office to end 1971 the 4th highest grossing movie of the year!! Making 2 personal bests for Clint.

Such a cool classic and so enjoyable! I'll definitely miss Clint Eastwood, he was legendary! Easily among the greatest action flicks ever made and not hard to watch or keep up with like most old movies. I don't really have anything bad to say about Dirty Harry, it's revolutionary and groundbreaking.

The one that started it all is none other than this action packed film, Dirty Harry! Clint Eastwood was really good! Andrew Robinson was great as the villain! John Vernon was good! Lalo Schifrin's music was good as always! The action scenes are top notch and these kind are not seen in every action film! The action is quite unique! Strongly recommended!

This film is the absolute matrix for a series of four more films with and by Clint Eastwood as well as a new way to deal with the problem of extreme crime and both the police answer and the political lack of courage in front of this emerging serial killing practice. We are in 1971 before the emergence of profiling that will come from the FBI in Quantico. So both police departments (led by elected sheriffs or marshals) and political personnel, like mayors and district attorneys, do not know what to do with such criminals and they tend to take a conservative stance hiding behind the very famous Miranda (the tree hiding the forest) and treating the crimes separately, hence erasing the serial dimension. Clint Eastwood reacting along the same line as the general public considered that the police had to be a lot more responsive, hence active and even brutal with these criminals, to the point of shooting first without any warning and asking questions afterwards, and only if they did not have any bullets left in their weapons. Some yelled at abuse of power. Others applauded to support the use of force to protect innocent bystanders. We were in the post 1968 period, the post Woodstock period, and the post hippy period. That strong stance on Clint Eastwood's side was the backlash at excessive tolerance and liberalism that was shown for what it had become in films like "Zabriskie Point" or "Fritz the Cat," a direct encouragement to criminal activities.That feeling of fear in the wide public was also racially motivated for some white people because that was the time when the Black Panther Party and the Nation of Islam started using the second amendment to justify their decision to carry weapons in public in full respect of what all whites could do. This feeling was amplified by the persistence of the Vietnam War and the very conservative policy of Richard Nixon. The number of casualties in Vietnam and the cost of the war, not to speak of the cost of the veterans who were lucky enough to come back in one piece though quite often severely impaired, becoming more and more visible and expensive, the people were quite ready to ask for a change in policy, a return of money in larger quantities to security within the country, which meant the end of the war. And yet it was still to go on for four years, increasing all the time the exasperation of the public.This film is still slightly slow but it is stampeding away in 1971. That was an action film and it had to be fast, though it is here more endurance than speed, and yet many of the tricks that were to develop in the next decades were already there: short sequences edited in clean cut ellipses. The camera did not have any time and energy to waste to give small descriptive details but it emphasized the successive moments in the action, even at times in a nearly impossible sequence, like Inspector Harry climbing to the top of the high building from which the serial killer had shot his first victim in less time than it took the coroner's team to wrap up the body of the victim and take it off the crime scene. Here the editing ellipse with Harry at the top point of the building and the body of the victim being removed makes it look extremely fast and meaningful.But this film is the matrix for many films to come that expose the inability of elected personnel, on both the police side and the political side, and even the judicial side, to understand that some urgent revision of police procedures has to be worked out – out of a magician's hat if necessary – that would at the same time respect judicial and legal procedures, empower the police to respond to such criminals at top speed, and protect the public against such criminals who cannot be saved in anyway because they like – sorry some of them do love – killing. From this obvious point to the idea that they have to be killed on the spot while committing a crime there is only one small step that is often climbed or taken in the heat of action. But we can be sure this film was the matrix of what was to become very popular detective – or rather nowadays police – series. Colombo is out and CSI or NCIS are in. And then you can work on details with Dexter or Criminal Minds and Bones. But it is always the same idea: these serial killers have to be neutralized at best – or worst – and eliminated from society at worst – or at best. For Inspector Harry the second option is the only one. Since then a lot of thinking has been done and particularly we have understood that such serial killers may be psychopaths or sociopaths, but they are necessarily super intelligent and they cannot be considered as intellectually underdeveloped, let alone handicapped or differently abled if you prefer.That's probably why Clint Eastwood will come back to that character four more times over the next seventeen years.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

It's hard to imagine just how shocking this movie was way back in 1971. To see a cop who DELIBERATELY sidestepped the law to dispense his own particular brand of justice was nothing short of a revelation. Dirty Harry believes in good, old-fashioned frontier justice (which didn't always jibe with the law as laid out by them as lays out laws). He also happens to be absolutely right in taking the law into his own hands: the system proves ineffectual against the likes of Scorpio, who manages to manipulate both the law and the media to his own nefarious ends. (One can only be thankful that John Wayne turned down the part: if ever an actor was more closely associated with the party line than Wayne, I never heard of him, and DIRTY HARRY cried out for- if you will- a maverick leading man. Clint Eastwood was the perfect choice, having made his reputation in Italian Westerns.) Director Don Siegel, one of the most talented filmmakers to ever come down the pike, reached his peak with this one. And that's saying a lot.

Review title: So much better than for what people predominantly remember it for.
Review_body: I suppose part of the reason Dirty Harry has become such a classic film, such a memorable film is because of its famous line revolving around Magnum handguns, the amount of bullets they can fire and weather or not a certain somebody feels 'lucky'. But apart from this line giving it legendary status, Dirty Harry is actually a very impressive and entertaining piece of film-making for a number of reasons.Harry Callahan (Eastwood) embodies everything that a hard bodied, hard boiled cop-come-anti-hero character needs to embody. The opening scene in which we see Callaghan is when he is called into the office of the mayor, someone who is superior in terms of authority, and he tells him exactly what's what in the sense he's been waiting around for a while before being called in; Callahan also closes his first scene with a line regarding policy, pointing out the line between what's right, wrong and the correct thing to do in a certain situation  this relates directly to an incident involving an attempted rape Harry foiled a while back. From this very first opening scene, we get the impression that Harry is a guy who will go against the rules and do things his way: "That's your policy, not mine" he tells the mayor and it sticks throughout. But rather than just get its protagonist correct, Dirty Harry contains a string of impressive and entertaining themes and scenes that all work together to produce a good film.I think what's interesting is the way the film takes a certain approach to its bad guy. Indeed, the first scene of the entire film is the killer himself making his first hit before a few scenes later showing us exactly what the killer looks like in full view. This isn't so much a detective story where the emphasis is 'who done it' as it is 'here I am, come and get me'. By showing the killer and what he looks like before he makes his mere second hit is an interesting move and a different approach to how certain other films may have tackled the material. Not only this but it sort of makes the audience a little self aware; instead of having us try and figure out who it is and why he's doing it, we get to see his face within the opening twenty minutes as he eyes up his next victim, giving off an extremely dangerous persona of the killer; a certain Scorpio (Robinson).But this is something else the film includes in terms of subject matter: voyeurism. The film is extremely voyeuristic; Scorpio looks at an attractive girl swimming in a rooftop pool through his sniper scope for a bit of amusement before shooting her; thus delaying the seemingly obvious murder just that while longer for the audience to mull over. Not only this but it gives the killer, who we know nothing about at this point since it's the first scene, an added sense of insanity that the audience will no doubt build upon. The film plays with who looks at who and the position of power within the frame; the girl may be on a rooftop but Scorpio is on an even higher rooftop; thus looking down. The same technique is played with through Harry himself. When he is attempting to scope out the killer with his partner on a rooftop after some bait had been set up, he uses the binoculars to gaze upon a naked woman in an apartment thus veering away from his job. He is again, looking with her having no knowledge of it and from an elevated position; interesting how the last time this happened in the film, it was Scorpio doing it and a murder followed soon afterward: will a similar chain of events follow now that the voyeuristic action has been carried out? They are there to lure the killer into killing once again, after all so all these things combine in the scene and will, hopefully, play on the audience's minds as they watch on.Away from analysis of the film, an historical placement must be mentioned. This film was made half a dozen years after the assassination of Kennedy; a person I now know a lot more about in terms of importance and conspiracy thanks to 1991s JFK, but the film was also made round about the time of Zodiac; a subject I was also informed a lot more on thanks to a recent film of the same name. I find it fascinating how in the opening scenes when they read out who wrote the letter, they tell everyone they'll be searching for people's birthdays between October 24th and November 22nd. Someone asks why; but the police merely say it's because of the Scorpio star-sign - nobody mentions 'Zodiac' or the Zodiac astrology setup; something I can only put down to the fact the word Zodiac would've just reminded audiences of the events that were going on at that time and in San Francisco. Dirty Harry is a film that intrigues with its narrative, disturbs with its scenes of voyeurism and insane antagonist whilst all the time feeling real and gritty enough to be a serious crime film. The scenes of Harry merely doing his job early on as he works on the case in-between scenes are great simply for the fact the screenplay is terrific. Dirty Harry is fast, fun, gritty, disturbing and contains enough deeper elements to render it far more memorable than for one mere line of dialogue; but what a line that is anyway.

This story takes place in San Fransisco.Scorpio is a sadistic serial killer who is lurking on rooftops looking for his next victims.Then he wants 100 grand from the city if they don't want more bodies.Inspector Harry Callahan takes the case.And he gets a rookie partner, Chico Gonzales."Dirty" Harry Callahan feels no mercy for the criminals.This is an introduction of Dirty Harry, the character that went on in four sequels.This movie happened in 1971 and it was directed by Don Siegel.Clint Eastwood is a tough man.Still at 80 he's a tough man.And he was born to play Harry Callahan, better known as "Dirty Harry".Andy Robinson is excellent as Scorpio.He really makes us hate the character, which only means he does some good acting work.Harry Guardino is marvelous as Lt. Al Bressler.John Larch is great as Police Chief.John Mitchum does great job as Frank DiGeorgio.John Vernon is very good as The Mayor.Ruth Kobart is wonderful as Bus driver.Reni Santoni is terrific as Chico.Dirty Harry is most memorable action movie.The scene where Harry tortures Scorpio on the field of Kezar Stadium is one memorable scene.The bus sequence is quite terrifying to watch, actually.All these kids are there in the schoolbus and this singing psychopath takes comes in.And of course the whole "Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk" line is a classic.And then, he pulls the trigger.

Review title: Changed the Action Genre For the Next 20+ Years!
Review_body: This is the movie that sets the mould for the cop action genre for a long time. Even Liam Neeson's Taken owes a lot to this movie.The hero (some times anti-hero), tough uncompromising, brutal, arrogant, funny (at other's expense) and all out of patience.I have a job to do...get out of my way...you don't like it...here's my badge!As a movie doesn't pack the oomph that it did upon its initial release, but still an out and out classic!

Review title: The perfect and almighty cop flick.
Review_body: Ahh, "Dirty Harry", the ultimate macho flick that is able to rise up your manhood. As a cop flick it goes further when criticizing the justice system (a dangerous criminal recovers his freedom under stranger circumstances). A bad-ass cop takes justice with his own hands and gun! Also, this cop known as "Dirty Harry", famous because of his bad temper, cool one-liners, not so methodical, is chasing a mad serial killer known as "Scorpio". (Is it me or Heath Ledger inspired his Joker character too much on him?). This leads to a series of unfortunate events that deal with violence that put the hierarchy cops in jeopardy. I can't praise this movie enough. It contains the required action, cool dialogs, realistic cop situations, and a memorable performance by Clint Eastwood.Watch it because it's not only a classic, it took the cop flicks sub- genre to a higher level. Word of mouth.

Review title: How to make an iconic character that everyone wants to be
Review_body: There are a lot of iconic film characters who have single handedly launched franchises: James Bond, Rocky, Indiana Jones, etc. but none are as gracefully done as Inspector Harry Callahan. Other than his .45 Magnum and a little spiel for the criminals that get in his way, there aren't any other gimmicks. Who you see is who you get -- a cop with a moral compass that doesn't let the law set its bearing. He's fast-talking, hard-nosed and merciless -- the cop that everyone wishes they could be but few have the balls to be. He's the model for how a singular character can drive a film.The first step is Clint Eastwood. Known mostly at the time for his Sergio Leone spaghetti westerns, Eastwood is a proved one-liner machine gun. He's the got the looks, the poise and the verbal delivery of a certified rebel, a man capable of anything. He makes "Dirty Harry" tick. All icons are made by their actors and Eastwood was born to do iconic.Part of what makes "Dirty Harry" a classic is that it's a vicarious movie-going experience. Everyone wishes they could just take justice into their own hands just like Callahan. The plot provides that same experience. Harry is a San Francisco detective on the trail of the "Scorpio Killer," a concept ripped straight from the San Francisco Chronicle headlines in the late '60s revolving around the mysterious Zodiac Killer who was on the loose. In a sense, Harry was born out of the country's frustration with the ineptitude of law enforcement in bringing that killer to justice. Harry does to the Scorpio Killer what we all wish we could've done to the Zodiac -- let him have it.An iconic character is also nothing without his lines and a clearly defined set of convictions as indicated in the script. Maybe one of his best lines (of many) is when he describes to some other police how he knew that a man chasing a woman in the street was intent to rape. It perfectly sums up that Harry is a man who doesn't wait to let the law define what's right and wrong. This vision for Harry is guided with strength by Don Siegel. Siegel carefully plans out his critical shots: a long distance zoom-out from the football field as Harry executes his version of justice and a wide shot of Harry above the bridge as he plans to intercept a school bus hijacked by the killer. Siegel creates iconic moments for his truly memorable character and it makes "Dirty Harry" a more unforgettable film.

Dirty harry is one of most famous roles from eastwood you can even say that it is his signature role that made him in a legend that he is today,and even if i think that eastwood is better director then actor here he still give very good performance and he had some iconic lines and badass moments,story in a film isnt nothing special we saw films like this many times but i still liked it even if it didnt offered nothing new or different,villain scorpio was a useful and he put some tension in a scenes like the one in a bus,dirty harry was a fine action film but i dont think it deserves such big classic status since except eastwood everything else was familiar and same

Review title: Great telelens photography, great Lalo Schifrin soundtrack, great slowburning story UP untill a quite ridiculous plot turn, which deflates the whole suspense. Still enjoyable!
Review_body: A hardboiled cop, who doesnt follow the rules, has to track down a serial killer. Will he find him and at what cost?Dirty Harry really is a riveting cop movie UP until an hour into the movie. Then all of a sudden there is a quite ridiculous plot turn which deflated all the suspense there was up to that point. I never like it when the writer doesnt take his movie audience seriously.Part of a series of 4 Clint Eastwood cop movies in which violence and retribution get glorified and civil rights and police procedures get ridiculed. This is a full on promo for police brutality and the way in which this story is portrayed I was rooting for the cops to get violent as well. That's the power of this classic, it really quite convincingly let's me believe that cop violence is good and the only way forward to combat crime, which ofcourse it isnt.Lots of fierce criticism followed when this movie was released in 1971, because of the glorification of violence and the disrespect for civil rights. In the second editon of the Dirty Harry series, called "Magnum Force" Eastwood has suddenly become a civil rights promotor instead of bashing those rights in like he does in this first edition. Clint Eastwood mentioned in an interview that he liked "Magnum Force" the best of all the Dirty Harry series (4).Besides the well known cool poses and oneliners by Clint Eastwood, lots of attention for technical detail went into this movie, resulting in great (telelens) photography for instance, the likes I havent seen much lately. A great, spacious sounding soundtrack by the legendary Lalo Schifrin is another one of those delightful technical details, which enhances the power of this already suspenseful movie.

Here's a solid cop police drama, that spawned a number or entertaining sequels, but also hails a new tough guy. Believe it, you've never met a more hardened cop, than inspector Harry Callahan. God, if every cop was like Harry, the world would be a much better place. This is Eastwood's best role, the role he was born to play. Dirty Harry has some bloody terrifying moments made that way by the killer nicknamed Scorpio, a brilliant if work of art performance by Andrew Robinson. Saddled with a new out of his depth sick partner Reni Santori, (Pepe in Seinfeld) we see all Harry's pet hates. He's a cop that works alone, and that's just how we like him. This Scorpio killer, a psychopathic sniper, has been making quite a nuisance of himself, and has put the city of SF under siege, threatening to kill someone else, if this ransom is not paid. And you can guess Harry's reaction. And it's up to Harry, to take out this madman permanently. And talk about kicking a killer when he's down in one scene. Another scene has the killer paying someone to have him worked over and transfer the blame on Callahan, who when viewing some photos of the battered maniac, harry defends himself, by saying "The killer looks too damned good". The bus scene with Andrew Robinson, really shows his sick, evil, pathetic self come to life. Although this isn't my favourite dirty Harry Movie, with the legendary line, nonetheless, is a solid action thriller, where at the time, would of upset some public, as to the rights of killers, where Death Wish followed two years later. But when it come to ridding scum, and delivering justice, Hey, I'm on Harry's side.

Admit it, you've all heard about the most powerful handgun in the world and about punks being lucky. The original Dirty Harry, starring Clint Eastwood at his prime, spawned multiple sequels and is still regarded as something of a crime classic.And yet I'd claim that the story itself is not all that memorable. Sure, it has a solid foundation and I do like the midpoint twist concerning the fate of the killer, but it is also a bit on the slow side and the runtime could be cut down quite significantly.Rather it's the character that makes this such a memorable film. We don't necessarily remember just how the crime got solved or what exactly the killer was doing. But we do remember how impossibly cool Eastwood as Harry Callahan was, walking down the street with a .44 Magnum in hand. There's even a scene in the film where Callahan has to talk to a jumper. And even that is cool.Not a perfect film by any means, but Dirty Harry is one of those archetype characters. A renegade, a loose cannon, a man who gets things done no matter what. And for that alone this is one fine film.

You got a cop from San Francisco who shoots first, and asks questions later, and his results always works. It's Inspector Harry Callahan(Clint Eastwood) aka "Dirty" Harry. He's mean, he's self-absorbed, he's also opinionated. However, he knows that the crooks and punks don't stand a chance against him. Especially when he carries a .44 Magnum. To other cops, that's not a gun, it's a cannon. Because it can blow your head clear off! Out in the Bay Area is a sniper known as The Scorpio Killer(Andrew Robinson). He's quirky, he's methodical, and he's a menace! Dirty Harry must go to all the extremes to stop this guy. His boss however, he more of a roadblock than a help. The killer goes too far when he hijacks a school-bus full of children. Harry jumps on top gets him every move, and give him a taste of his own taunts. These things aren't normal everyday things, and Dirty Harry isn't your typical cop. This movie is great, and a major keeper as well. See it! 5 stars!

Review title: Clint Eastwood before he looked like Clint Eastwood
Review_body: This is the first of what was to go on to become five Dirty Harry films. They have now come out in a DVD box set, digitally remastered, so I thought it time to have a rummage through them again. I can hardly believe it was more than forty years ago that Clint Eastwood made DIRTY HARRY. He did not at all look like himself then, in fact he was surprisingly bland and uninteresting at that age. What makes him interesting now is all the character in his face, of which he had little trace back then. Although I bear him a deep grudge because of the way he treated Sondra Locke, I have to admit he is amazingly talented, as witness his directorial work especially (see my reviews). It is interesting in retrospect to consider why this film and its sequels became such a huge hit. The film in itself is very good but nothing to jump up and down with excitement about. Director Don Siegel did an excellent job of trying to make it look as good as he could, and San Francisco is always a plus as a location, as we know, especially when you have got Bruce Surtees as the cinematographer. But the reason why this film 'clicked' is because Eastwood's character Police Inspector Harry Callaghan challenges all the idiotic liberal safeguards for the excessive rights of criminals which ignore the rights of victims. This is one of the most serious dilemmas of our times, more important now than it was in 1971, for this crazy imbalance of 'rights' which is continually perpetuated by all the functionaries who are intent on self-destructing our societies from within hold every criminal precious and dear to their hearts, whereas victims can just get stuffed. Dirty Harry shows his disgust clearly, a disgust already in 1971 held deeply by probably a majority of the American population, and certainly a majority outside the urban conglomerations of the trendy Coasts. (And where in the USA is trendier or more wildly liberal than San Francisco, the setting of this film?) The story plays to this angle by showing a raving psychopathic murderer who is going around shooting people from rooftops, and the San Francisco District Attorney lets him go, after Dirty Harry has caught him and put him in jail, because his 'rights' have been infringed and the rifle he was using to assassinate people in the streets was seized without a warrant. When Eastwood asks what about the rights of the victims not to get killed he is told 'it is the law'. Naturally we all internally cheer when Eastwood resumes his pursuit of the madman in his private time and defies 'orders from the fifth floor'. By the way, in one shot Eastwood is entering a café and we can see a cinema nearby, which is advertising his own film PLAY MISTY FOR ME. An early example of product placement! It is a good joke, but can only be glimpsed for a moment. Don't production teams like to amuse themselves! This film was the first cinema appearance of Andrew Robinson, who plays the psychopath brilliantly, and who then went on to appear in 103 titles, and there is no record I know of his having murdered anyone since 1971, so, well done Andrew, you have restrained your murderous impulses for four decades! That's true professionalism! This film is entertaining if you don't mind a certain amount of violence. John Vernon is good, as usual, as the Mayor of San Francisco, but then he wants to let the bad guys out of jail too. I thought Ruth Kobart was very good as a terrified elderly driver of a hijacked school bus with the amusing name of Priscilla Platt. It takes a lot of talent to look that terrified when you are just sitting at a steering wheel and when your character is called Priscilla Platt. Some of the school children get slapped around pretty badly by the psychopath, so sensitive people will not find this film easy watching in places. The clever ruse the psychopath uses to try to discredit Eastwood by pretending Eastwood beat him to a pulp, namely by paying someone else $200 to beat him to a pulp so that he can pretend it was done by Eastwood, is one of the most shocking aspects of the film. Never trust a psychopath, that's my motto, which is why it is so difficult to cast a vote sometimes.

"Dirty Harry" was the film that boosted star Clint Eastwood to super star status. Climbing down from the saddle, Clint found the ideal character...the urban gunfighterIn San Francisco, a serial killer known only as the Scorpian has begun killing innocent citizens at random. A young girl is shot while swimming in the latest killing. Inspector Harry Callahan (Eastwood) has been assigned the case. The Scorpian has left a note demanding $100,000 or he will kill a priest. The Mayor (John Vernon) has to find the money while Chief of Police (John Larch) and Harry's boss Lt. Bressler (Harry Guardino) are concerned. The three have questioned Harry's methods in the past but are willing to give him another chance.Harry is assigned a new partner, Chico (Rene Santini). Harry's partners in the past have not fared too well so Harry is not happy over having to break in a new man. Harry goes to lunch and while eating a hot dog foils a bank robbery. It is here that we are introduced to Harry's .44 magnum...the most powerful hand gun in the world. It is here that Harry utters the immortal words to one of the robbers..."Do ya feel lucky punk?". Harry tells Chico that he is called "Dirty Harry" because he seems to wind up with all of the dirty jobs.One of these jobs is the rescue of a potential suicide from the top of a building. Harry and Chico set up a stake out to lure the killer into a trap. The killer takes the bait but escapes after an exchange of gunfire. The killer, upset over being caught in the act, raises his demands to $200,000, Harry offers to bring the money to the killer but has Chico follow out of sight.Harry is surprised by the killer and is beaten. Chico is wounded in an exchange of gunfire. Harry manages to stab the killer in the leg which disables him and he loses the money in the confusion. Chico becomes disenchanted and decides to leave the force to become a teacher. The killer meanwhile, has kidnapped a young 14 year old girl and holds her for the $200,000 ransom.Harry and Inspector De Georgio (John Mitchum) track the killer to a football stadium where Harry captures him. The killer fails to disclose the location of the young girl. Through legal technicalities, the killer is released. He has a tough beat him up and has the blame placed upon Harry.
Harry begins to follow the killer on his own time. The young girl is found dead as Harry continues his pursuit.The killer takes over a school bus with several children aboard and.................................Eastwood is essentially playing Harry as "the man with no name" in a suit. He brings out that big gun at every opportunity but does so in the interest of law and order. There's no love interest here but there are some nude scenes in a strip bar to satisfy the men in the audience. Andrew Robinson, in his first film, makes a great baby faced villain and no he is not related to Edward G. Robinson as has been reported in some circles. John Mitchum, the brother of Robert was a poet of some renown and would appear in two future films in the series.Followed by four sequels.

Review title: The Most Serious Unserious Movie Ever !
Review_body: This is a memorable movie for sure. Not for being an attractive action thriller only, but for leaving such a deep effect on the American pop culture, and the hero's image in American movies and TV shows for following decades. Inspector ('Dirty' Harry Callahan) is the godfather of every ideal, angry, and maverick American cop since the early 1970s till now. Here, you'll find some perusal for the dark side of the American good hero (imagine a "John Wayne" who can shoot bad guys in the back), while battling a super evil criminal who assures that the modern civilization's law misses some savagery to execute its justice.However, the movie's main downside is that super evil criminal. The script didn't present the character of (Charles 'Scorpio Killer' Davis) as a criminal inasmuch as the crime itself. He steals, blackmails, kidnaps, and kills. Most probably, in the first draft, these very crimes were done by many criminals, then it got modified to make more unity and one villain. Though the final result was uneven and unbelievable. Furthermore, we didn't watch any motive or history for (Scorpio). They made him *The Psychopath Killer* to justify his mega craziness, and compensate for his unstoppable extreme crimes. But with loose absolute evil, read: exaggeration, the character lost its credibility totally.It gets ironic when the antagonist is dealt with by that weakness, while all the caring goes to the protagonist. Clearly, (Harry) is well presented as a sincere cop, who lost his wife, hence dedicated his life for his work, as well as released all of his passions into his war against crime, where no victory without equal violence. And if you felt that the treatment of the whole thing was that superficial, wait to watch the rest of the franchise, where the action ate the drama. Actually, in here, it's the sole time to see (Harry) that desperate to throw his badge into the river, but it mirrors the fact that this movie wasn't meant to be a series.The nudity, the profanity, and the violence are all here. Done for a realistic factor to seduce the critics, or for a commercial factor to seduce the audience, both ways I didn't buy it, or like it. These goods were / are / will be ugly, distractive, and have nothing to do with arts. Day after day, they became inhumanly overabundant, let alone how I believe that they establish, and legislate, degeneration in societies as well!On the upside, the music's lamentable sense was so touching and profound. You'll get it wholly in the last scene, and sorrowfully you won't find it in any of the next sequels. The cinematography was so tense, a little realistic compared to the action movies at the time, and artistic; to draw and color (Dirty Harry) along with his world eloquently. See how (Harry) had that special halo around him, showing as a high shining giant whose kind of isolated and deeply in pain.(Clint Eastwood) seemed bigger than life. It's enough to remember the shot when (Scorpio) looks surprisingly, from the bus that he kidnapped, to see (Harry) standing in black shoes, suit, and sunglasses on the bridge ahead of him.
