Dirty Harry Callahan delivers his own version of justice and when someone known as the scorpio killer starts randomly people for a ransom Harry deals with it his way even if it angers his superiors. Dated but still fun and a must watch for those into action or even just Clint Eastwoods catelogue of films.

Review title: Simple yet captivating screenplay allows Clint Eastwood to drive the star vehicle
Review_body: Dirty Harry is one of the most legendary and popular characters which has spawned numerous imitations not just in Hollywood but different movie industries across the world. Who else better to pull this off than Clint Eastwood who is flawless and effortless in portraying the role.Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) is a trigger happy unconventional cop but always brings results. When the city is threatened by a sniper aka Scorpio Killer (Andrew Robinson) who keeps putting down random victims holds the city police for ransom to stop his rampage. Harry is assigned for the task and they come up with a plan. The sniper gives them a slip after repeated plans lure him to their cage. This time the Scorpio killer takes it personal and asks Harry to deliver the ransom for a final showdown.Follows a textbook story telling process which later becomes a formula for the genre. A detailed introduction of the antagonist followed by the protagonist only after which the plot surfaces (as wafer thin as it might be) slowly building up to a final showdown. Though the Scorpio killer initially comes off as weak and mad, his character progresses steadily during the course of the story giving multiple dimensions and levels to his character. It is not comprehensible how the police department misses the sniper even multiple sightings with all the man power, pre-planning and technology. But the star is undoubtedly Clint Eastwood who carries the entire weight of the movie and even gives it a considerable boost with an uninterested look on his face, the hype surrounding him because of his volatile trigger happy nature and sharp one-liners.Simple yet captivating screenplay allows Clint Eastwood to drive the star vehicle

Review title: One of the defining film of the 1970s
Review_body: Released on Christmas Day 1971, "Dirty Harry" transformed Clint Eastwood from cult figure to superstar.   Another maverick cop thriller, "The French Connection," was released a few months earlier, and it may have won the Oscars and garnered the critical acclaim, but "Dirty Harry" is the true classic of the two, and the most influential.  Great action magnificently directed by Don Siegel, the master of the genre, great dialogue, and relentless tension make this the ultimate detective thriller and one of the defining films of the 1970s.

Dirty Harry is the first and easily the best in the series of "Harry" movies. It has been analyzed, dissected, reassembled, then analyzed again. Lots of social commentators had huge concerns about "loveable" Harry. They claimed he was glorifying violence--he was acting like a fascist !!, he was making violence fashionable & hip. They were not amused by his fun line "do you feel lucky ?--well do you --punk ?" They claimed Harry was having too much fun toying with his adversaries. Well, all of that may be true, but it still remains a hell of a good movie. Harry Callahan the San Fransico cop who hates people who break the law. And ..real baddies ?? he cant stand them. When a mad bad person (played by Andy Robinson) starts killing people and asking for a ransom, (after he kidnaps a young girl) Harry becomes mad. I mean real mad dog mad. His methods do not amuse City Hall, but Harry cannot be stopped. He knows this type of man needs to be terminated-----for good. This is a very good movie...as Harry would say "you have to ask yourself one question, do you feel lucky ?" If you do--watch this movie. (The music by Lalo Schifrin is excellent).

Review title: Pure bravura man stuff whats it's all about
Review_body:
*Careful of a topless woman through the window in the alley scene.*
"Now you know why the call me Dirty Harry." "Because I have a dirty fart hole and its Hairy." Nah just kidding about that last sentence, but they do ask that question like twice. and he answers it. This is the stuff dreams are made of. I had seen this flick yrs ago but only now reviewing it intently I can process that it is dope as it was. Why the heck is this dope? Harry is just such a nonchalantly tough dude without even effort, almost to a hilarious way as the film opens the way Harry is so unwaveringly smooth in his assuredness, so unmitigated in his smooth strolling, his face being 1 expression, there is one little moment where his expressionless face gives it away though to reveal a face of nonstop sheer cold destruction and it's when he is asked how many rounds his weapon has by the incapacitated badguy on the ground and Harry, strolling away, turns around to return to the badguy and it's here his face looks like a freakin Eagle, eyes having this slyness/smugness to them for that instant. Without saying anything it's all told in that, that is the expression of a merciless twinkle of happiness in the dismantling of foes that he does. Whoa.I just wish we would get more and more length to the movie but then again that's why it is the beginning of a series to satiate audience's craving for more of Harold's escapades. The main badguy is revealed and is a very kinetic personality, just appears and starts annihilating people with kind of a boyish face. That *could* have some symbolism. I know from they (Eastwood has a say?) choose this actor precisely because he has a face like so which could mean that having boyish tendencies is not good and to just grow up, embrace adultness, the way Harry is. Or that's not for the audience and just for the badguy to show that he's a crazy kid inside, trailblazing villain for sure. In a way he is a mirror to Harry's own boyishness because Harry is not complicated, more 1-note. As an 'Inspector' he definitely appears to figure stuff out good in those streets like at one point he and partner 'maneuvers' through alleys and buildings like strategy to know where the badguy is to show up which is fascinating. The 1-note aspect of the movie is appealing, no need for 'layers' to things, it's kind of comic book which is... just so good. Music and cinematography are also good. I like that nothing is explained things just start happening for the plot and just I'll add everyone in there goodguy and badguy could use some milk and cookies.

Review title: Good story and cinematography with OK acting.
Review_body: Dirty Harry can be argued as having been the pioneer of cop films which paved the way for many more cop films later on. As this genre is increasingly popular, it is hard to compare and to see how this film works in regards to itself. Keeping in mind that this is a very early cop film I would have to say that it did a pretty good job.I don't think I have ever actually seen a young Clint Eastwood before, and it was rather unnerving to see so much likeness of how he looks now compared to then. He did a good job of playing the cool, tough cop who - though is a man of the law, doesn't really follow it. He judges his morality as higher than others and in the name of justice, does what he thinks is right in order to correct the wrong. Andrew Robinson who plays the killer gives an erratic performance which befitted his character. Very wild and out of control, his 'crazy' eyes are characteristic of his character, as are the animalistic screams he makes.The story is pretty average, with the focus on Harry and his obsession on getting the killer. The film kind of shows that the law isn't very good at protecting its citizens though, with Harry being depicted as the only one who really cares if the killer is caught (with the exception of his partner Chico). But the story was pretty engaging and had good action scenes.There was also some pretty great shots in this. We get some pretty good point of view shots from Harry and the killer's perspective. But noticeably, the most impactful shot is probably the one where Harry is standing on the bridge as the bus travels on the road below. For some reason it reminds me of the terminator, what with his sunglasses and all.However this film does have some issues with race, gender and social hierarchy. For one, all the high ranking officers/ powerful figures are white and the robbers who appear briefly are black. The killer himself while is white, is feminized in the way he walks and screams while Harry is the epitome of masculinity with his calm demeanour and low voice. There are hardly any women in this film too, except to be victims or someone's wife, not to mention that the killer is made out to be homophobic as he targets a gay man in one of the scenes. Furthermore the many reasons why dirty Harry is called dirty comes into play, not just as a referral to him doing all the dirty jobs, but also because he is a sort of peeping tom.Read more movie reviews at: championangels.wordpress.com

One of Clint Eastwood's most influential films.Harry Callahan is a character that is almost impossible to see on the movie screen today, an uncompromising and vicious policeman who despises crime and does not hesitate to use his gun against criminals.The film is as uncompromising as its main character, showing how criminals avoid punishment, but that in the end they still get the fate they deserve.It shows how journalists are sometimes irresponsible and judges naive and gullible, and in the end Inspector Harry Callahan has to deal with the
killer himself. Andrew Robinson brilliantly portrayed the psychopathic and manipulative killer.The cinematography is interesting and the music suits the atmosphere of the film. The direction is interesting, the film has an authentic look of the early seventies and perfectly evokes the atmosphere of that time.An unforgettable classic.

Review title: One of the coolest cop movies you'll ever see
Review_body: It spawned four sequels and countless imitators, redefined a genre, brought in millions at the box office, and was both hailed as one of the best action movies in years and derided as fascist propaganda. It provided a major boost to the already red-hot career of its star Clint Eastwood. It introduced one of Hollywood's most iconic heroes and baddest bad guys. Forty years later people still quote lines from this movie- including some that weren't in it. There is no doubt that Dirty Harry is one of the most influential movies of the seventies, and one of the all time great cop movies.Eastwood stars as Inspector Harry Callahan, the original cop who doesn't play by the rules. He has no time to worry about proper procedure, isn't particularly careful about following orders, and makes no effort to be likable. He pulls no punches, doesn't care who he offends, and he keeps his job because there isn't a man on the force with sharper aim, better instincts, or harder stones than him. He may not make many friends, but he gets the job done. But he faces the toughest job of his career, taking down the mysterious sniper known as Scorpio. Scorpio is every cop's nightmare. He's driven, intelligent, and completely insane, with a sadistic streak a mile wide. He delights in causing pain, kills for the sheer fun of it, and is always one step ahead of the police. He's not picky about who he kills, but can meticulously his crimes days in advance. And he loves to make the city of San Francisco play his games. He reminds me more than a bit of Heath Ledger's Joker, who he may have been an influence on, and there are some chilling parallels to the DC snipers.Admittedly, many parts of the film seem clichéd by today's standards, from the rookie partner to the superiors who constantly make the wrong decision and call the hero out on the carpet. But this movie is the reason they became clichés. And there are parts that are brilliantly original, like the telephone chase in the middle. You'll know what I'm talking about when you see it. The pacing is excellent as well, with long periods of tension leading to explosive action scenes, with the best being saved for last.I give the director and cinematographer high marks for the camera work, including sudden close-ups, long panning shots, and extensive use of first person view. They've also made very good use of their locations, and really captured San Francisco, both the glamorous (downtown, the Golden Gate), and the seedy (liquor stores, topless bars, gay druggies in the park).Now Harry Callahan was and is a controversial figure, both within the film, and among social commentators, though not as much so as back in the seventies. He's a constant headache for the DA and public affairs, and in real life he'd probably spend half his time on suspension. I admit his knowledge of, and regard for, the rules of evidence and the rights of the accused are pretty low, even for a movie cop. I can't help but sympathize with him though. If I saw a naked, knife-wielding man chasing a woman down an alley, I'd shoot to kill. I'd also look for ways getting around the search warrant requirement if I knew that a fourteen year old girl's life depended on finding the perp. But it's also clear that he did go too far in apprehending Scorpio at the football stadium. Busting into the grounds keeper's hut without a warrant is excusable, same for skipping the Miranda rights. But there was no excuse for a police officer beating a wounded suspect, especially on the area of the wound. If this were a war movie or a private eye film he could get away with it, but for a cop it's just too far. This also leads to the one point where suspension of disbelief becomes impossible. I cannot believe that a police department, even in San Francisco, would just let the suspect walk. No matter how badly his rights had been violated, they would still find some technicality to hold him on. And they would certainly keep him under constant surveillance if he were released.These issues aside, Dirty Harry is still a solid thriller, and excellent 'guy' movie, and one of the best cop dramas ever made. Don't let the kiddies see it, but if you're high school age or older it's definitely worth checking out.

An unhinged psychopath is on the loose gunning down innocent people in scenic San Francisco for kicks. There's only one man to stop him: Harry Callahan. A handsome, unfazed and world-weary police inspector who is the living embodiment of a man who "follows the beat of his own drum", Callahan is as much a headache to his superiors as to the crooks who fear and dread his wrath. In their cat and mouse game Callahan and the villain who calls himself "Scorpio" stroll, run, and shoot leaving a trail of smashed objects, bloodied figures, scared pedestrians, dead bodies and a lot of pissed off people. While not the classic it's made out to be, "Dirty Harry" is one of the most notable action flicks whose entertainment value and influence were felt way into the end of the 20th-Century and made Clint Eastwood a legend. The film is also a neat glimpse into Nixon-era America with it's hearse-like cars, sideburns, funky soundtrack and that clear, somewhat sleazy and shady vibe that went hand in hand with a warmth and energy that made the time special and which this world has yet to see again. "Well do you, PUNK"!?

Review title: The quintessential cop movie produces one of Hollywood's great tough guys
Review_body: Maybe I'm 50 years too late to be watching this for the first time, but I'm not coming from the rose coloured glasses of nostalgia. Obviously coasting on the winning formula they had with the titular character, Clint Eastwood is the ultimate bad ass and it's fun to watch him play up that shtick. The movie surrounding him may be secondary, but it's still solid, with a suitably detestable villain and fast paced plot. Not sure if the cop movie cliches were already well established at this time or if this movie really laid the foundation for things to come, but familiar genre tropes abound. Under the modern lens, some things didn't age well, there is some cringey racial insensitivity, next to no female representation and the underlying idea that a rogue cop that shoots first and asks questions later is inherently a good thing, but it's a product of it's time and should be viewed accordingly.

Review title: Defining movie and role for Eastwood
Review_body:
I would dare say one of the more important films in Eastwood's rich career. His Harry has become an icon and a definition of the character he will play for the next few decades. Stubborn, full of hatred for almost all people, but always ready to act justly according to his postulate, which is why he often conflicts with the law. Certain criticism in this film is obviously directed at the American law that allows a multiple psychopath-killer to go free. A psychopath called Scorpio, whose real name we don't even know, is creepy and dangerous, a worthy opponent of Dirty Harry. His character is based on the famous Zodiac killer who harassed, killed and left messages to the police. The film balances brilliantly between a thoroughbred shot and a suspenseful thriller, and the Magnum is currently becoming the most popular gun in the world. We see a great characterization of the characters seemingly in small and irrelevant scenes and conversations where we learn a lot about what Callahan really is, like a scene where his lunch is interrupted by a bank robbery, when he talks to a potential suicide, to a partner or his boss and law enforcement. What a cult classic it would be without the iconic final showdown and the very end of the film. After solving the case, but in his own way, Harry showed one contrast that was in keeping with his character. Although he has sorted everything out with a big bang, he still ends up in silence and without a word, far away from us because he is aware that as a representative of the law he still cannot protect those who should protect the same law. The interesting thing is that the directorial debut of Eastwood (Play Misty for me) was released in the same year, and we also have a collaboration with Don Siegel, the director of Dirty Harry, who got a role in the film here. What a great year in the resume! (This is 1971, a full fifty years have already passed). A real classic that will be given to us four more sequels, but also an influence on many films that were made after this. I can say that this was a very brave move to make a film like this in the very beginning of the seventies. Eastwood has made better films, of better quality, but this is certainly the cornerstone of his career, probably the most iconic and recognizable because in later films he will always weave at least a little Inspector Callahan (Gran Torino is a film about retired Dirty Harry, right?).
I feel lucky, even though I'm not a punk.

Review title: Loaded with right-wing tropes, but a fun detective potboiler all the same
Review_body: "Dirty Harry" appeared in the early part of the conservative revival of the late '60s and early '70s, but the tropes of that movement are already fully manifest in the movie. The backlash against the counterculture, the preoccupation with supposed sexual deviance, the fine-tuned racism, the belief that the government is too soft on crime, the certainty that the only real justice is that which is dispensed through the barrel of a gun: it's all here, in almost the exact form that it still exists on AM talk radio, in misspelled Facebook posts, and in the jeremiads of right-wing politicians. But while the ideology of the "Dirty Harry" universe is an unintentional caricature, the movie is undoubtedly well-made and well-acted. Andrew G. Robinson is playing society's stereotype of a serial killer, but he's doing it marvelously. Clint Eastwood isn't working outside his comfort zone, but like John Wayne or Arnold Schwarzenegger, he doesn't need to. "Dirty Harry" follows in the footsteps of hard-boiled detective movies of Hollywood's yesteryear, and points the way to future buddy-cop potboilers. Although it launched a mini-franchise, the original is in many ways its own sequel, with clearly defined acts that allow for a substantial number of call-backs and self-references within a relatively short runtime.

Review title: The most important American-made film of the past 50 years!
Review_body: Recently I've considered drastically negatively re-appraising Clint Eastwood's work, both directorially and as a thespian, as a knee-jerk reaction to his constant defense of the more racially-bigoted face of conservative America, but because of what his work has meant to me as a cinephile over the years, plus in tribute to everyone else's work involved in this film, particularly director Don Siegel's, that simply wouldn't be fair.As well, you're basically getting, boiled down in its 103-minute timespan, 45 years after the fact, the main dilemma facing the USA. Whose rights are more important--the good guys' or the bad guys'? If they're equal, should they be considered equal, and what does that mean to the law enforcement and judicial systems? Quite simply, THE most important American-made film of the past 50 years. NOT my very favourite (that's '2001: A Space Odyssey'), but the most significant.And it hasn't aged a single day because of it.

Review title: Eastwood at his best - and dirtiest!
Review_body:
In spite of its age and dated looks DH is probably one of the best cop movies to come out of Hollywood. It spawned a host of variations on a theme, even though some would argue DH took a few ideas from the 1968 Bullitt.The idea of a cop trying to bring criminals to book, but using tactics otherwise outside the law, was quite a novel idea back then and was probably an indictment of how the crimewave in some parts of the States had spiralled during the liberalised late 60's and early 70s.Of course if Mr Harry Callaghan had tried such unorthodox methods of arrest in these politically correct days you can be sure the criminal would have sued for millions of dollars, shouting human rights violations and demanding the cop be arrested & jailed for a thousand years.Which is a salient point in a way, because back in the 70s such Correctness was exactly the kind of thing Callaghan was fighting against along with creaking police procedures of arrest.Not only does he find it hard enough keeping tracks on Scorpio as he causes mayhem in the streets of SF, but he also has to battle the law & order system. Is it any wonder he steps out of line when justice seems to support the alleged criminal rather than protecting the innocents...sounds so familiar these days.Eastwood really got his foot in the Stardom threshold with this movie. Somehow I don't think an ageing John Wayne or Sinatra would have had the same kind of steely glare as Eastwood, especially during the final standoff with Scorpio and Harry recites his infamous "Punk" line. Nobody has a tighter jawline than Eastwood at times like this.
Eastwood expands on his previous Dollar "man with no name" characters to good effect: essentially we have a man who is more a renegade, a man who tries to live outside the restrictions of law & order in order to achieve a legitimate goal, although unlike the Dollar films Eastwood becomes a little more cultured in the streets of SF rather than way out in the middle of some western desert.The bandits he challenges to duels in the Dollar films are no different to the criminals he challenges in Dirty Harry, and even though he has the law on his side, its often not enough.Siegal's direction and the script never lets up for a minute coupled with a very good musical score. But the best part is of course the stand-off at the end. What Eastwood does with his badge is perhaps one of the great pieces of symbolism in movie history and probably had a million liberals up in arms!The less said about the sequels the better: they seem to follow the Jaws trend, Magnum Force being competent but The Enforcer et al just get steadily worse.Pick the best and make his day, Punk!****/*****
A simple but efficient cop movie with important stakes and a great introduction to the character by Eastwood. This one really aged well even 50 years later.

Review title: no wonder they call him 'Dirty' Harry
Review_body: There are certain movies that just wouldn't work if Clint Eastwood wasn't in them. Namely, most Clint Eastwood movies. Take 'Dirty Harry.' Remove Eastwood, have someone else play the title character, and you've got just another early 70's cop thriller. I watched it the other day for, I think, the first time since it came out. It was quite a shock, seeing Clint with enough hair for three people. I was also surprised at how graphic the violence and nudity was for a 'mainstream' film from 1971; it must have been just this side of an 'X' rating at the time. But aside from that, it was the same Clint Eastwood we've been watching for fifty years. Nobody else plays the super-cool cop/gunslinger/secret service agent/whatever in quite the same way. Nobody else would make it seem so believable. Part of it has to with the character's basic contrariness, part of it's being the 'strong, silent type' because the character is always a man of few words. But he's not infallible, like some heroes. The trick that Eastwood pulls off that almost no one else can is that he's badass cool even when he's screwing up or getting the hell beat out of him. He's not afraid to play the fool and make mistakes. There's something about the persona he projects that keeps us from thinking he's a dumbass. It's not just an 'I don't give a damn' attitude on his part, it's that combined with an underlying self-respect and code of honor. It's more of a 'I don't give a damn what other people think because I know what's right' attitude, and it always shows through. Eastwood had already established the basic character in the 'spaghetti westerns' of the sixties. But in 1971 under the auspices of his own newly-formed Malpaso Productions, he brought a somewhat more talkative variation to the screen as Harry Callahan of the San Francisco police. (Hey, Los Angeles has Joe Friday and San Fran has Dirty Harry.) The thriller about a go-his-own-way cop was a huge hit and trendsetter; imitations have come out on a yearly basis ever since, not to mention four Dirty Harry sequels. The original focuses on the Scorpio killer and it set the tone for the others; there were, if not exactly running gags, recurring situations, such as Harry constantly being questioned by his superiors and others about his violent tendencies and Harry essentially telling them to shove it. For example, the first film contains the quintessential Dirty Harry line of dialogue (parodied in 'Police Squad!' by Leslie Nielsen and elsewhere). When told what the police department's policy regarding use of force is, Harry responds, "When an adult male is chasing a female with intent to commit rape, I shoot the bastard. That's my policy." The mayor is forced to concede, "I think he's got a point."

I watched "Dirty Harry" years ago and didn't really like it. I started watching it again today but just didn't feel like finishing it. So I am just giving this overrated film a 2/10. It is just typical 1970's action fare -- too much bravado and prejudice with too little substance. And I'm not someone who looks for bigotry everywhere, as that can be counterproductive, but it is pretty blatant here. It didn't even make sense how the note at the beginning said one bad word and then everyone pretended it said "scorpio" and the plot continued on that path. Just not good, and I usually like Clint Eastwood movies.

Dirty Harry, the film that rocked the 70's and that rocked the world on its release date. Remembered as a cop thriller and to be remembered as one of the best to date. Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) who must find and bring down sniper expert Scorpio from causing any more extreme terror to Sanfrancisco City. By this he demands the sum of $100,00 to be paid to him, before he kills his next victim. Wild car chases, classic action are all in this film, keeping the suspense flowing rapidly and the action exploding dramatically, but worthy not of its 18 certificate. Director Don Siegel recreates the suspense and action like from such films as the Fugitive.With Clint EastWood at the helm of the acting role nothing could go wrong, adding great dialogue to Harry and fab characteristic development. With his Magnam in his coat pocket and an air for causing trouble, Dirty Harry explodes onto the screen with full on action and cant look away acting.

Review title: Reactionary message movie with many logical fallacies
Review_body: The more I think about this film, the more the way this message movie was presented and the way it has been received by many really annoys me. I'm especially sensitized, given that Bush n' co. spent most of the last decade taking away our rights in the name of "security" & "safety". They must've loved this film!The message seems to be a very reactionary one. Rights/legal protections are bad. Rule of law is useless. Vigalante abuse of power is great.This movie is full of several logical fallacies, generalizations and other issues. It sets up a False Dilemma -either ignore the laws & get to kill the guy OR he goes free. It also sets up a Straw Man argument of picking a very rare/unlikely instance of a super psycho as an argument of why honoring the rights of criminals is bad.Sure, it's really easy to set up a grossly exaggerated portrait of an inhumanely disturbed racist monster who killed at random, raped & threatened children, threatens priests & had no redeeming values. Then show how all those pesky civil rights helped him go free and kill again. Blame the civil rights! Showing the rare instance when something that GENERALLY is a good thing failed (NOTE: it didn't work because HARRY did not follow the rules- not because the rules were there!) and then use that as an excuse to rant about the rules and make it seems as if there is no point to them.No grey areas. No thoughts as to what argument means if you carry it out the whole way through. No consideration on why those rights exist or the positives of protection, especially for someone who may be innocent.Think about it- how often does SF suffer at the hands of a madman serial killer? Not since the 70's. I just checked the crime stats for SF for the last 2 months. Not a single murder. Sure, SF isn't crime free there were probably a thousand or so burglaries, robberies, etc. But I'd much rather have strong rights and let a few people (mostly non-violent offenders) get to go free because their rights were protect then to not have Miranda rights or the 4th amendment. I'll take my chances that a psycho killer may come if it means I don't have to live in a fascist state with no expectation of privacy. I don't want some admittedly racist misanthropic cop who feels that he can doing anything he want & shoot anyone he wants if he even *thinks* they're being bad. What happens when Harry shoots an innocent person? What would have happened if that guy at Kezar stadium had been innocent and Harry had beat the crap out of him? Is that OK because Harry's *usually* killing bad guys?To be fair, I did check and it looks like "exigent circumstances" that allow for a LEGAL warrantless search if "necessary to prevent physical harm" doesn't appear to have become solidified until after the film (in '76)And what was the point of the lingering shot of the killer wearing a peace sign belt buckle? Was it merely supposed to be ironic because he was a killer? Or was it meant to equate a merciless killer with those stupid"peace-loving hippies" who are causing murders to go free by advocating for rights and opposing oppressive police practices?In the end, I chose to read the final scene as Harry goading the killer into an action so that he had an excuse to shoot him. Then Harry realizing he had no right to uphold the law as an officer if he could not follow the laws. So he threw away the badge as an admission of his failure. However it seems to me as though many reviewers saw his action in an opposite light, of choosing to reject the rule of law and embrace his vigilante ways.

Review title: The Beginning of the Dirty Harry ERA
Review_body: TITLE: Dirty harry was released on December 23, 1971 and the runtime was 102 minutes. Dirty Harry is a 1971 crime thriller film produced and directed by Don Siegel, starring Clint Eastwood, Harry Guardino and Reni Santori. This was the first in the Dirty Harry series. Clint Eastwood plays the title role, in his first outing as San Francisco Police Department Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan.SUMMARY: A serial killer who calls himself "Scorpio" (Andy Robinson) murders a young woman in a San Francisco high-rise rooftop swimming pool using a high-powered rifle from the top of the 555 California Street skyscraper. When SFPD Inspector Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) investigates, he finds a spent shell casing and a ransom message from the killer, promising more deaths if the city does not pay him $100,000. The chief of police, with the agreement of the Mayor (John Vernon), assigns Harry to the case and arranges for extra support. Later, Harry waits for his lunch in a local café, but notices a robbery-taking place at a nearby bank and tells the café owner to call the police and report an armed robbery in progress. While he waits for reinforcements, the robbers emerge from the bank, forcing Harry to confront them alone. During the confrontation, Harry utters to one of the robbers: The next day, Harry is assigned a rookie partner, Chico Gonzalez (Reni Santoni). Harry notes that his partners always get injured (or worse), and that he needs someone experienced, but the Chief gives him no choice. A police helicopter foils Scorpio's second attempt at murder while he is targeting a black man in a park, but Scorpio escapes. The next night, he manages to kill a young boy from another rooftop. Since Scorpio's last victim was a black man, the police believe Scorpio will pursue a Catholic priest as his next victim; feeling "owed" one for the disruption of his earlier attempt. The police set up a sting, with teams on rooftops throughout the city, but leaving the rooftop Scorpio used in his disrupted murder attempt clear, and providing a target of opportunity, a priest at the Saint Peter and Paul Church. Harry and Chico wait for Scorpio on an adjacent rooftop, Harry with a high-powered rifle and Chico with a spotlight. When Scorpio appears, a shootout ensues but he eventually escapes, killing a police officer. Infuriated that his plans have twice been foiled, Scorpio kidnaps a teenage girl, rapes her and buries her alive. He contacts the city and demands twice his previous ransom, giving the city until 3 a.m. the following morning, when the girl's air will run out. The mayor decides to pay, and tells Harry to deliver the money to a location at the docks with no back up. Without permission, Harry wears a wire, has Chico follow him, and tapes a knife to his shin. When Harry reaches the drop point, Scorpio contacts him through a public payphone, sending Callahan on a journey between various pay phones in the city, in order to separate the inspector from any back up that he may have. However, Harry's wire allows Chico to follow him. The chase ends when Harry reaches an enormous cross at Mount Davidson, one of the city's parks. Scorpio instructs Harry to drop his gun and the money, then to face the cross and stand up against it. Scorpio then proceeds to beat Harry before revealing that he has "changed his mind" and is going to let the girl die anyway, and kill Harry as well. Chico arrives at the scene and shoots at Scorpio, saving Harry. Chico is shot, in the ensuing shootout. While Scorpio is distracted, Harry stabs him in the leg with his concealed knife. Scorpio screams hysterically and escapes without the money. Chico survives his wound, but tells Harry he will be resigning from the force.QUESTIONS Why did Harry have to get a new partner? Why was Harry looking for the doctor that treated Scorpio? Why was Scorpio living and working in nearby Kezar Stadium? Why did Harry stand on Scorpio injured leg? Why Debralee Scott body was found overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge? Why was Scorpio release from all charges? MY THOUGHTS: This was the beginning of the Dirty Harry ERA. This movie kept you on the edge of your sit right from the beginning. I thought Andy Robinson did a good job as his role as the bad guy. Once again however this was a movie that no leading lady. Sure, there was a lot of action. However, it takes more than action in my eyes to be an excellent movie. In my eyes, a movie must have a leading lady if it wants to get 10 weasel stars. Since this movie had no leading lady I can give this s movie 8 weasel stars at best.

"You know, you're crazy if you think you've heard the last of this guy. He's gonna kill again," Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) sighs to his superior. A maniac (a fantastic Andrew Robinson) is on the loose, killing anybody who comes to his liking, usually on the edges of rooftops with a polished sniper rifle. His wild, long blond hair blows in the wind with the prowess of a lion ready for an attack, his deranged face snarling with noxious elation. He is the Scorpio, a murderer who finds himself amused when blood spills onto his hands. Callahan has done everything to stop him, yet he has escaped the grip of authority with aggravating repetition.Unfortunately for the so-called Scorpio, Callahan is no Frank Bullitt and is definitely not a Jacques Clouseau-type. Carrying a .44 magnum, which he dubs "the most powerful gun in the world," Callahan is unflinchingly acerbic, humorless, and unafraid to sidestep the law and take justice into his own hands.When Dirty Harry was released in 1971, it was a new kind of cop movie. It was one with an outrageous amount of violence and one with a lack of a moral compass. Simply put, it was a source of serious controversy. Police brutality was something left untouched by most American films, and to have a hero slightly deranged himself was something far and away from the well-defined good guy/bad guy cliché. But to take Dirty Harry seriously would be like viewing a comic book with a realistic lens; it's a piece of seedy pulp that takes the police thriller genre and stretches it out with operatic carnage and dark alley sleaziness. The streets of San Francisco are like the frames of a graphic novel, colored with dim electric light by night and saturated with disconcerting warmth by day. The film lives in a world where crime runs around with menace, becoming nearly casual to its citizens. Harry Callahan is like Batman, minus the suit, Batmobile, immortal sidekick, and underground lair. He is most well-defined in an early scene where he sits down in a diner for a midday snack. That moment of peace, though, is interrupted when he notices a bank robbery in progress across the street. A few of the criminals have been gunned down, but one lies on the steps of the entrance, bleeding and moaning. Rather than arrest him, Callahan is inspired to taunt him, make him transform from predator to prey in a matter of seconds. He deadpans his way through a mini-speech that seems prewritten as he cocks his gun: "I know what you're thinking. 'Did he fire six shots or only five?' This is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world. It would blow you head clean off. You've gotta ask yourself one question: 'Do I feel lucky?'" We discover that the thief is lucky – Callahan has fired all six shots.But it becomes clear later on that he most likely already knew that all six shots were fired. When it comes to a dirty criminal, however, why not play a sick game of Russian Roulette? Callahan would prefer to teach brutal lessons and give bad guys a taste of their own medicine; Miranda rights and the amendments are for sissies.Harry Callahan was the original tough-guy detective, remaining to be a brute force of fortitude and pointed courage. Without Eastwood, he wouldn't have that ominous edge by his side. It's a performance of precise emotion. He delivers every line with a diverting softly spoken voice, only to later explode with an awesome capability for violence. As he whispers his few words, we can only wonder what's going on in his head. Callahan is such a legendary figure in cinema because every move he makes is recognizable, embedded into the foreboding underbellies of neo-noir. Dirty Harry is iconic for a reason. Few cop movies have been able to thrill without the slight glitter of Hollywood lure. It can be sickeningly violent, but that's only because one foot is glued on action and the other is on realism. Read more reviews at petersonreviews.com

Review title: The originator of the bad ass hero....
Review_body: **POSSIBLE SPOILERS BELOW**Finally seeing this film, its as good and 'groundbreaking' as was advertised.  Now I see where other films like Die Hard 3 & Along Came A Spider got the 'bad guy sending the good guy on a wild goose chase' idea from (with the public phones).  I'm not sure if this is the first film to do it, but its definitely the earliest film I've seen it in.  Dirty Harry is the original bad ass good guy; I've dabbled in the character's other films like The Enforcer, etc but never the original......and I must say it's a pretty damn good movie.  It's intriguing throughout; the 'Scorpio' character is as creepy as it gets.  You just get such a good and relieving feeling when Dirty Harry finally gets him in the end.  Clint Eastwood fits the Dirty Harry character perfectly; the now famous 'do you feel lucky' line is absolutely classic.  It was good to finally experience the originator of it all; this movie has spawned a lot of children in action cinema, all praises due to the father....Dirty Harry.*** out of **** stars.
" Clint Eastwood" owns this character. Even if the film is bare bones, there is atleast an ark that draws its themes into focus.

Review title: One of his greatest early "middle period" movies and arguably his best movie.
Review_body:
Clint has starred in and directed some wonderful stuff and this is a particularly good example and justifiably famous. It has so many stand-out moments of drama and wit and irony. He
plays such a fantastically defined character, that in one way or another it shaped the rest of his career. Like some fine musicians that have distinctive styles, we have glimpses of most everything
at least in earlier form, of his trademark stylistic craftsmanship acting. The humor, the sneer, the gunslinger, the sense of irony, his most famous lines, and probably the best example of his
delighted grin when "the punk" just "gots to know" if this is his lucky day or not. I suppose if anything is more or less left out or merely implied, it's the tenderness
that he reluctantly trots out in his later work like million dollar baby, which wasn't so much reluctant as delayed, or grand torino.Anyway in a career as truly splendid as his, where as a director/star his work seems to get better all the time, this movie, for me anyway, was a milestone, and 50 years later has not been surpassed.Predating taxi driver, I'm not sure that movie would have come into existence without this preceding it. Andy Robinson puts in a howling performance in his semi fictionalized version of the actual
zodiac killer. Set in early 70's San Francisco, at a time when a person could still afford to live in that beautiful city, as I did just a few years later, it's also a great period piece for the town, as movies
like James Caan's 'Thief" depict so much of older Chicago, my main home, which digitalization ruined utterly years ago, as it has to the whole planet.

This film is a true masterpiece, an original and well done very interesting story that keeps you hooked, about a serial killer (loosely based on the zodiac killer). This movie has an amazing casting and acting from Clint Eastwood and his character is so perfect. There is tons of action and iconic scenes, great effects, lots of suspense and very tense moments. Lots of iconic and memorable moments, just an amazing and very good movie. Masterpiece 10/10.

Review title: The Inimitable Clint Eastwood Gets Down and 'Dirty'!
Review_body: Clint Eastwood was a Western icon for a fistful of spaghetti Westerns and cynical American copycats. When he strapped on his .44 Magnum to stride the streets of San Francisco as Inspector Harry Callahan, known to the squad as Dirty Harry, Eastwood turned his frontier persona into an urban cowboy on the mean streets of our urban world and helped him cultivate an iconic image.In Dirty Harry, maverick San Francisco cop Harry Callahan is ordered by the city mayor to stop a pathological, bigoted serial killer who calls himself Scorpio (Andy Robinson who proves to be a wonderfully odious villain). The psycho wants $100,000, or he will continue his bloody work. The mayor and others are willing to capitulate, but Eastwood disagrees, sensing it would be just the first payment. Eastwood bristles when teamed with young Chico (Reni Santoni) against his wishes (Chico fails Callahan on three counts, by being new to the force, Mexican-American, and, perhaps worst of all, college-educated); but he reluctantly begins to accept the junior partner. Scorpio says he's buried a teenage girl somewhere in the city and will let her die unless the town comes up with $200,000. Eastwood gets the job of delivering the money (backed up by Chico), but eventually pursues his own, extralegal route to nail Scorpio.Dirty Harry is both of its time and timeless. Visually it reeks of the early 1970s with enough graphic violence quite a bit of gratuitous female nudity on display. But at the same time the story is a gripping game of cat and mouse between cop and psycho killer that transcends the setting and time period. It is a visceral film, directed with urgency and style by Don Siegel, embellished with some of the coolest electro-jazz confections.But above all, Dirty Harry works because it is driven by the inimitable Clint as Detective "Dirty" Harry Callahan. Harry, the hero, is a flawed anachronism - a frontiersman in modern society. His tough-as-nails persona is one that has often been imitated. He bucks authority because he cares more about justice than he does about rules. Harry Callahan is both more openly scornful of the law, an equal opportunity bigot and, thanks to Eastwood's perfectly calibrated performance, more compelling an individual, than Siegel's earlier neo-vigilantes.In real life, we'd be terrified of Harry and the loose cannon he calls a handgun. On the big screen, you can't help but applaud his frontier justice as Eastwood mouths the now iconic line "Do you feel lucky, punk?"

Review title: Setting the foreground for vigilante cop movies.
Review_body: In what may be Clint Eastwood's defining role as a screen icon, the narcissism and heroic setup is what makes this movie such a draw for young male fans. This was the pivotal point in Clint's career that would make him a legend I believe, even more of an impetus than the 'man with no name' trilogy. In Dirty Harry, Clint defined his charisma and the secured the monumental franchise.Yes, I grew up in the 70's and watched Eastwood's movies and especially loved Dirty Harry for the same reasons why any other red blooded kid would. Clint's style is what makes him and this movie so magnetic. With his classic and signature steely-eyed grin, whispering voice and stoic righteousness, that in itself is just the surface. Harry Callahan is a no nonsense cop out to mend justice with his unorthodox approach. But technically this makes him a rebel to a flawed legal system that inadvertently protects the perpetrators and bad guys.So the argument that this is a right winged biased approach to law and order is faulty due to the fact that Harry is actually a rebel and defies the ineffective system that is confined to so many left winged statuetes.Dirty Harry is basically a cop movie which the plot is fuelled by the hateful murderer and the justice sought by one man, Harry Callahan. It's a beautiful and gritty film with all of it's inner city backdrops of San Francisco. The hippie era had reached status quo by the early 70's and I could see how the theme of the story took political chances.But it's a good cop movie. The murders are realistic, the violence still holds up and the tension builds inevitably as the denouement face off between Scorpio and Harry's chase scene reached its climax.Unfortunately the sequels relied to heavily on political pundits for justice. We don't need to be taught these elementary lessons on morality and that is what gets old to me. It's more interesting, as in the original Dirty Harry, to see a portrait of a lawman face adversity when trying to uphold what is right and what is fair in an unfair legal system, only to be hindered by the laws and police hierarchy.

Review title: Do You Feel Lucky In Best Of The Best Cop Western
Review_body: Renegade San Francisco cop dirty harry Callaghan tracks down a brutal serial killer with grit humour and a deadly fire arm. Perhaps this is the one movie i have seen the most often over the years, From the original release through reruns, video DVD and now revivals back in the cinema. A classic like this defies any potent criticism it has Eastwood's career defining role number 2 as is very much a film of it's time.Watching today the none PC attitudes are jarring but the violence has mellowed with time but this is as much a film, in which the city of San Francisco stars every bit as much as Clint Eastwood.As a foot note i expected at the time for Andy Robinson to go on and have a big movie career but somehow it just did not happen for him yet he is quite brilliant as Scorpio the deranged gunman while the dialogue throughout the film remains sharp and terse and instantly quotable.

Review title: The first and the best, an Icon is born.
Review_body: Though there were several actors interested in the role, we can all be thankful that it was a 41 year-old Clint Eastwood that ultimately landed the role and film history was made.In this first (and best) installment of the series, we have Inspector Harry Callahan of the San Francisco PD on the trail of Scorpio, a sadistic serial-killer, whose attempting to extort the city of $100,000 - but the sum soon rises as do the stakes. The role of Scorpio is brilliantly portrayed by the little-known/under-rated actor Andy Robinson, who, after this movie should have gone on to do great things, but instead, he was soon cast for a role in a soap opera pathetically enough; of which he was soon fired from merely because "he's that mean man, from that scary movie". Knowing this, one can easily surmise that the soap opera crowd must be some of the softest and most delicate people in the world. Anyway back to the movie, Eastwood's good friend and mentor, veteran film director Don Siegel helmed the project, which was filmed in and around Clint's home town of San Francisco, the primary location for all but one (Sudden Impact) of the series.Owing much to the fact that Scorpio's a homicidally insane night-owl, who has a very busy night-life, many of the movies most crucial scenes occur at night, which were strikingly captured by the masterful eye of veteran cinematographer Bruce Sortees. The scene on the roof-tops involving the attempt on the catholic priests life, where Scorpio gleefully shoots-up the rotating "Jesus Saves" sign is the most perfectly composed/photographed night scene I've ever seen in a movie, another great one is the scene involving the labyrinthine layers of Kezar stadium (which dramatically ends with one of the best helicopter shots ever). Scorpio as you'll see, is a man whose not burdened by a conscience and leaves a trail of destruction virtually everywhere he goes and though he's highly impulsive, he's not stupid and ropes along Callahan, The Mayor and the SFPD for almost the entire movie, first with extortion attempts, then he tries his hand at blackmail - and more extortion.When watching this first outing of Dirty Harry one quickly realizes just how perfectly suited the cast and crew were, it's a marvel, a thing of sheer perfection and as a result of their combined talents, every single aspect of this film seems to fall perfectly into place and crystallizes at that moment, resulting in the creation of an iconic screen hero/film series. Though four more "Dirties" would follow, the first film still stands out as the best of the lot; but what are the reasons behind that, as there are so many to consider. First of all Eastwood's great as always - that's a given. However for me it's the thrillingly compelling performance of Andy Robinson, that elevates this film to the next level and the series never had a more effective antagonist. Huge props must also be given to Don Siegel, whose skillful direction fully compliments the film and keeps the pace rolling at a high level of intrigue. Siegel's direction is so to the point that there's not a single scene wasted, not even a single wasted frame.Another stalwart of the series is composer extraordinaire Lalo Schifrin (the man behind the Mission Impossible theme), who scored all but one of the series five films. But it's in this film that his music is most memorable and effective, Schifrin's music has a way of capturing the vibe of Scorpio's murky, night-time world, pitch perfectly. I'm particularly found of the tension his music stirs up whenever Scorpio is coldly eyeing his victim from a distance. Schrifin was, again, the perfect choice of composer, which as stated earlier is a recurring fact, when considering the people who where behind this classic film. Which finally brings us to George Milius, the films screen-writer, whose contributions are invaluable to this films lasting greatness. Milius is primarily remembered for his iconic "Do I feel lucky" routine, which Harry loves to taunt criminals with; his famous words are, of course, reinforced by the presence of his infamous partner - the mighty Smith & Wesson 44 magnum revolver.What this all adds up to is the best cop drama ever made and it's scary to think of how badly this movie would have sucked, with someone else in Clint's signature role. Give praise to the exploits of Inspector Callahan, as this series has been an institution of greatness for nearly the past half a century.

Review title: The greatest rogue cop of them all
Review_body: Dirty Harry Callahan just might be the greatest anti-hero that cinema has ever known. Like the movie says, you don't assign him, you just turn him loose. Obsessed with delivering justice at whatever the cost, Harry makes you wish that there were more cops out there just like him. Dirty Harry starts off the eventual 5 movies in the series with a bang. All 5 are great but it is the original that I keep coming back to. Everything about this movie is well done and entertaining. The period soundtrack is wonderful. The streets of San Francisco are practically a player in the movie. Great shots of the city circa 1971 abound. Scorpio is the perfect bad guy. You can't wait to see him get his. Despite Clint Eastwood's many movie roles, and especially his westerns like The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, Harry Callahan is his best character in my opinion. He gives Harry just the right amount of humor and humanity so you know that Harry is just human and not some superhero. When Harry and his .44 Magnum are in town, the bad guys better watch out. Bottom Line: Buy the Dirty Harry collection on DVD and you will never want for police dramas again. That is, if you feel lucky. Well do ya punk?

Review title: Good parts cannot make up for the inconsistencies and uneven flow.
Review_body: This is kind of a hard one to decide about. First of all, Clint Eastwood is totally overrated as an actor. The part where he says, "Ask yourself: do I feel lucky," kind of reminds me of Terminator 2, where they kind of go fishing for memorable lines and the anticipation falls short. It felt totally cheap and forced. The second time he recites the famous screed, at the very end, to the killer, felt overdone and overused. This movie kind of feels like a composite of known serial killers in real life, and they could have been a bit more creative. You have the Scorpio killer in the movie, which is a take on The Zodiak in real-life; you've got Harry as a Peeping Tom, which was what Ted Bundy was known for; and you have a killer who targets gays, like Jeffrey Dahmer did. After watching this movie, I got the impression that Eastwood himself is a bit of a perv, as a recurring motif is "Peeping Tom." Such as his one line, where, while on a stake-out, he says to himself, "You owe it to yourself to live a little, Harry," while spying on a swingers' party when he should have been looking for Scorpio!! I thought he was a supposedly good detective!! Needless to say, there's a lot of nudity interspersed into the story. There's very little character development, as Harry is a person you either love or hate, and you mind is not changed throughout the very singular and narrow narrative. In fact, this feels more like a documentary in the style of 'Cops' than it feels as an actual movie. The music is very good, however. I give credit to Lalo Schifrin, who does a fantastic job. The plot elements are intriguing enough to give this a watch, I suppose. Andy Robinson's performance as a likewise- one dimensional Scorpio killer is at least passable. What this really was, was a personal statement about life in the 1970's and not much more.

Review title: The best 70's cop thriller movie. A classic!
Review_body: Dirty Harry alongside with Sergio Leones "the man with no name" must be Clint Eastwoods most famous role. The fact hat this movie spawned a franchise of 5 films is no surprise. It's even director Michael Manns favourite movie.To sum up the character, he's the incarnation of the "bad cop" expression. He follows no rules, but gets the job done. he has he's own sense of justice and this gets him in trouble with the law. On the other hand, he saves life, and get's the crooks off the street. So the main question is, does the cause justify the means? I think everyone have heard of Diry Harry, and he's the character most people think of when they hear the name Clint Eastwood. He's though, he's grumpy, how can you not think is an awesome character? And at some point everyone have heard the line: "Do you feel lucky? Well do ya Punk!?" For this classic Clint Eastwood cop thriller, I give a 8/10. if you don't like the genre, you won't think much of it. But if you like action, thrills and enigmatic characters, this is the film for you!

Warner Brothers is set to release the Dirty Harry Ultimate Collector's Edition so I paid respectful tribute to their cash grab by borrowing an old 4:3 version of Don Siegel's genre defining, tough as nails cop movie. What I loved about my version was how it looked like old TV reruns from the 70's: faded, scratchy, well-worn...and dirty. I'm sure the new widescreen, digitally remastered version looks sparkling by comparison, but who wants to watch a gritty film with all the grit buffed out? I want my Dirty Harry filthy.The movie itself is pretty much what you'd expect if you've never seen it or (like me) haven't watched it in a very long time. The crooks are scumbags, the bureaucrats are pussies and the law is the blast shield these weasels all hide behind. Enter Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) and his best (and only) friend Mr. 44 Magnum (Smith & Wesson). When Harry is finished, this same blast shield resembles a splintered, bloodied and hollowed out exit wound to the back of a human skull. Early on, Harry, gun extended, asks a wounded bank robber: "I know what you're thinking. Did he fire six shots or only five? Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk?" Immortal words. As far as characters go, there's not a lot of depth to Harry. We get the hint his wife has been killed and that no one on the police force really likes him, they simply fear him. Harry is ice cold, trigger happy, racist, misanthropic, cynical and is incapable of spelling due process, let alone defining it. In other words, this guy embodies the typical American in the early 1970's, a collective soured by the senseless carnage of the Vietnam War. In fact, Harry is a right winger's wet dream where the crooks are corpses long before they get a chance to beg for "habeas corpus." I suppose in many ways, Harry embodies what the typical right-wing American wishes they could have done to the Viet Cong: blow em' away and put an end to this mess. But sadly, this is a movie and, wish fulfillment aside, things in the USA would get far worse (mounting Vietnam casualties and Watergate) before they would get better. In the end, Harry's six gun justice leaves him as disillusioned at the end as he was at the beginning and aside from some blood lust being served, the audience has to ask the same questions they must have been asking about the Vietnam War: Why?What is refreshing about watching a movie like DH today is its disdain for political correctness and its balls out ability to show society as a cesspool in need of a good scrubbing. They don't make movies like this anymore and I'm shocked they don't considering how easily the Neo-Cons have made Watergate seem like a petty political prank and how Iraq is fast becoming our generation's Vietnam. The truth is, we could use a revamped and retooled version of Dirty Harry. Maybe this time around he could be a blood thirsty Secret Service Agent who snaps and goes on a rampage in the oval office. Final Draft here I come.http://eattheblinds.blogspot.com/

Review title: Gritty Realizim will always be king
Review_body: This is a great film about one detectives fight against a almost too liberal society. I as a liberal cannot believe that this movie does not offend me, but it brings to life the gritty realism's that do effect us as a liberal society. When this film was made killers like the Scorpio killer in this movie were getting the easy brakes, look at Charlie Manson and his disciples of hate, they all should have been sent to the chair for their sins, I cant stand people who would glorify this man and his deeds by wearing a T-shirt with his face. I am all for free speech but as it is stated in the Bill of Rights where the first ten amendments are located, free speech is only applicable when it does not infringe and , or take away from the rights of others. It is in this that Dirty Harry rises. It shows that if you are a murdering coward you should be punished. I love when Harry throws away his badge at the end of the movie showing that he is tired of the sickness that is all through out the corrupt system of police and it's over long litigation process. This film is at it's best when it showcases the hunt and the lengths to which Clint Eastwood's character will go to avenge peoples rights. This is best stated when Harry's superior officer tell him the Scorpio Killer has rights and that Callahan infringed on this rights. With that said Eastwood's brilliant character replies back in a satirical manner "I'm all broken up about that mans rights!" That is what this film stands for, too many bureaucrats allow criminals to roam the streets while they worry about falsely criminalizing people who can't afford insurance, or a place to live. These people go to jail while your local town maniac sits on his couch waiting for his next fool moon murder. Come on, we need Dirty Harry back on the case.

Review title: The First and Most Disturbing of the Dirty Harry Series.
Review_body: For those of us who lived in the Capital Beltway area during the sniper shootings a few years ago, this movie hit pretty close to home. It's a pretty frightening feeling knowing someone could be watching you and targeting you for a killing for no reason other than they just feel especially mean.Some scenes in this movie are hard to watch. In fact, I won't watch the scene where Scorpio terrorizes a bunch of children on a school bus. (Incidentally, I have lived around natives of Scorpio all my life. Most of them are wonderful people.) I really feel sorry for the actor that played him. This part must have ruined his career. I think someone on this site said he got death threats after playing this role. It's a pity so many people out there can't distinguish make believe from reality. Andy Robinson did a fine job. Scorpio is the most despicable movie villain I have ever seen.This is by no means adverse criticism of this movie. I am a huge fan of Clint Eastwood and of the Dirty Harry series, except for maybe THE DEAD POOL, and I've already commented on that. They really draw you into this movie and tells a riveting story.I think people who say Harry Callahan meted out vigilante justice are totally misreading his character. I have seen this movie many times over the years, and Harry always followed police procedure before shooting anyone. The only times he shot at anyone was (1) if they tried to shoot him first and (2) when a fleeing suspect wouldn't stop after he ordered them to. In most police precincts across the country, an officer can shoot a fleeing suspect if he doesn't stop after being ordered to do so.The scene that really gets my Irish up is when Harry asks the DA who speaks for the murdered Deacon girl. The DA says, "We will, if you will let us." Yeah, right. While we're at it, let's hire Charlie Brown to coach the Washington Redskins. Every thinking person knows that the government has an uncanny knack for screwing up a wet dream.In spite of its disturbing aspects a great movie. 9.5 out of 10.

Review title: We need more cops like Harry.
Review_body: This gritty, violent 70's cop flick is still one of my favorites. Yep, this is the one that started it all! Clint Eastwood IS Harry Callahan, a tough San Francisco inspector who always gets the job done, no matter how dirty it is, hence the name. Running around is a sniper killer (calling himself Scorpio) who is trying to extort money from the city through the murder of innocent people, a deed he thoroughly enjoys doing. Harry, of course, doesn't approveat all, and sets out to stop him. However, even though Harry does the right things, the written law is against him and Scorpio plays the system for all he can, that is, until Harry decides enough is enough. The movie never lets up and is filled with witty dialogue and thrilling action. The two leads are both very convincing in their roles and the psychedelic 70's music is excellent. One of the best scenes has Harry foil a bank robbery (by shooting most of 'em) while calmly finishing his hot dog and at the end, delivers the famous "Do you feel lucky, punk?" lines to a wounded robber whose shotgun lies just a foot away. You gotta love the .44 Mag! This film is not to be missed! The four sequels, while enjoyable, don't even start to come near the quality of this masterpiece.

Ok I can only say this in SIMPLE WORDS.
DO NOT REMAKE THIS FILM.
IT IS A MASTERPIECE. THERE IS ONLY ONE CLINT EASTWOOD. SO DO NOT REMAKE THIS FILM.
IT CAN'T BE REMADE. LEAVE IT ALONE.
When he holds up that GUN to that MAN. And pulls the Trigger and SMILES. When the GUN is empty. And the Man is on the Ground in BLOOD. CLASSIC MOVE BECAUSE HE ALREADY GAVE IN ON HIM. THINKING IS GUN WAS LOADED LOL.
There is Only #1-Clint Eastwood and DO NOT REMAKE HIS MOVIES.

Review title: One of the common classic justice movies of 70's decade
Review_body: The movie was much like western genre movies that Clint Eastwood ever act as solo character who want to bring the justice all alone and kick some asses. I couldn't give the movie a lot of credit cause in my opinion the story line was not much interesting.

Dirty Harry is an action crime movie starring Andrew Robinson, Harry Guardino and Clint Eastwood in the main role as Harry "Dirty" Callahan, a detective with an ethic far beyond his peers and a giant hate for everyone. Even though he's presented as a terrifying and awful character, he's likeable and relatable and we can't help but to be on his side. Eastwood was born to play this type of roles and his performance is magnificent along Andrew Robinson who also did a captivating performance. The screenplay is well-written and the soundtrack is compelling. Do I feel lucky today? Yes, I do!

Dirty Harry is amazing. Simple as that. It's over 30 years old and it's still better than most of the cop movies out today. Eastwood defined "Bad ass" with his role. The villain he matches wits with is great, too. Never in the history of every movie I've ever seen have I wanted a villain to die more badly than I wanted Scorpio to. I know that sounds kind of morbid, but it's true. He is just a horrible scumbag of a villain, and all the way through I was rooting for Harry to get the S.O.B.This is the definitive Clint Eastwood (cop) film. If you've wondered why he's so popular, just watch Dirty Harry and you'll see why. If you're not standing up cheering when he jumps on that bus, check your pulse- cause you just might be dead. It's a ultimate "guy's night in" flick.My Rating: 10/10

I think anyone who hasn't seen Dirty Harry, still a staple of late night television in Britain, is either lying or died before it came out. Everyone must know the plot by now: tough cop Harry Callaghan ( Eastwood) is assigned to catch a psychopathic serial killer, Scorpio, played by Andrew Robinson, whose innocent and clown like features make the role more chilling.Basically Harry has little time for the hippyish liberal philosophies that were taking hold in America at the start of the seventies- Dirty Harry is filmed in a San Francisco just coming out of the hippy era and ironically Scorpio wears some hippyish clothes- and is a tough cop of the old school who believes violent criminals should be hunted down and, if necessary, killed off. No wonder in America, which was suffering a big increase in crime when Dirty Harry was released, the character proved popular with millions of Americans even if one critic predictably referred to the film as fascist for its brutal approach to solving crime. However, who is the real fascist: a decent cop trying to stop a psychopathic killer on the rampage or Scorpio,the serial killer terrorising San Francisco.From the opening credits where a young woman is gunned down in a swimming pool to the end where Scorpio is blown away by the most powerful handgun in the world, the action never lets up and both Eastwood and Robinson play excellent roles. Dirty Harry, even if you have seen it a million times, will always make your day and spawned four excellent sequels that are just as good as the original. If you can, try and watch all five of the Harry Callaghan films as the characterisation is fantastic and the wisecracks as good as anything from James Bond.

Review title: Who knew that the film world could churn out a film as great as this....
Review_body: Unbelievable cold-blooded vigilantism played by Clint Eastwood as Detective 'Dirty' Harry Callahan, the cinematography, the score, the script, its all pure genius wrapped in a bundle called "Dirty Harry". The story of a crazed roof-top psychopathic killer who goes by the name 'Scorpio' (played by Andy Robinson of 'Hellraiser' I believe), Scorpio loves to leave notes to the mayor about how he will kill different people of race, gender or whatever it may be, in order to receive a ransom he feels he is entitled to. Harry Callahan (Eastwood) sees it a different way.... Callahan doesn't like seeing killers get their way and he really doesn't like Scorpio. The Mayor, Chief of Police and any other authority thats in Harry's way are determined to appease the killer in order to hopefully desist this carnage from going on any longer, Harry again sees things a different way. The mayhem that ensues is just cinematic genius and an unbelievable script that will keep you compelled from beginning to end. This movie will either make you or break you of the action/thriller genre. 9/10 stars will definitely suffice, brilliant work overall by the crew of this film.

Review title: "Dirty Harry" is a great cop movie
Review_body: "Dirty Harry" is a great cop movie. It features Clint Eastwood in the eponymous role, trying to chase down a psychotic killer played brilliantly by Andrew "Garak of Deep Space 9" Robinson.The plot is fairly simple. Harry stop Scorpio (the killer). In between Harry gets to foil a few other crimes - my favorite being the hilarious scene where Harry talks down a man from committing suicide. This is a prime example of some the delicious black humor running through "Dirty Harry", that helps elevate it above the dross. The main killer is particularly effective because of the way Robinson portrays him, as if a wild man is trapped inside a normal citizen. The killings themselves are violent and brutal and perfectly match the film's gritty nature.Eastwood suits the dry, sarcastic, down-beat Harry to a tee as he's perfected all the looks necessary over his career. He's a cop you don't ever want to mess with. His partner - who have previously had the career of a Spinal Tap drummer - plays surprisingly well off him, considering the circumstances, even if his fate is somewhat inevitable.I'd recommend "Dirty Harry" to any fans of the cop genre, as Dirty Harry - the cop, not the movie - is a great character.

There are mountains of praise for Dirty Harry, and all of them are deserved. But one thing that gets me is the justification of freeing Scorpio for the third act that comes off as pure propaganda: would any police department really free someone in a mask who shot at them so freely? The story swerves into a bit of disbelief when Scorpio, after injuring a few police officers and is in turn injured, is suddenly let go after being shot in the leg. To add insult to injury, the whole thing is turned into a right-wing nonsensefest where Harry goes on about victim's right (a valid concern) but is shot down by the personification of a smug liberal (from Berkeley, no less!) simply to get us to the third act. Even then, it's a bit hard to take seriously since they did have something to hang Scorpio on: shooting a police officer.This is a classic movie that deserves its fame. But the one flaw is that instead of writing a segue into the third act, they decided to go into an unrealistic rant that demonizes one half of the political spectrum for absolutely no real reason. It just seems a bit silly, but don't let this ruin the movie for you. Eastwood's always good, Siegel is at the top of his game, and maybe you can get a chuckle out of seeing their attempts to push the movie to the end by pathetic political doublethink.

Dirty Harry is the grandfather of the modern renegade-cop flick, such as Lethal Weapon, Beverly Hills Cop, Bad Boys, and countless others.However, its age shows and it lacks some of the refinement of modern cop flicks.  First off, let's be clear what Dirty Harry is: despite Callahan's title, this is not a detective movie.  Rather this is a pure, unadulterated cop flick, and plotwise a rather generic one.  There is very little actual detective work and there is no whodunnit subplot.  There is a bit of one-on-one, cat-and-mouse intercourse between the cop and the crook, but unlike say Insomnia, Seven, or Eastwood's own In the Line of Fire, Scorpio is by no means a sophisticated mastermind.Rather, he is a generic, carefree blend of society's worst stereotypes: thief, rapist, killer, kidnapper, pedophile, conman, racist...you name it. Because Scorpio is such an obviously awful person and because he's able to so easily exploit the system, the movie comes off as a bit one-sided politically.  At times the movie seem superficial to the modern viewer; some of the trimmed fat might even be construed as outright plot holes.  For example, it seems silly that the DA and the judge need to lecture Harry as if he'd never heard of the Bill of Rights.  How would someone rise to Inspector without at least a basic understanding of the legal system?Nevertheless, Dirty Harry is high on style and a must-see for any fan of the genre.  It's a back-to-basics movie on how to characterize and develop a cop lead.  And of course, it has Harry's immortal speech.  The action is okay too for its time, and its impressive that Eastwood did all his own stunts. All in all I give it an imdb 7.

Whether it's the hard cop, psychologically-thrilling villain or unscrupulous police department, it's clear Scorpio is menacing San Francisco. Whether it's midday shootings or midnight terrors, it's a city's worst nightmare and one that will not cease.Clint Eastwood flourishes in his role as Harry, who's as dirty and stone cold as they come. The world is the limit for him, but he is conflicted with his duties and moral obligations. With a killing spree capturing the innocent lives of Californians, Harry goes to incredible extents to track and take down an elusive criminal. It's an uphill battle, though, as it appears both the criminals and department have no respect for the spirit of the law. Dirty Harry shies away from being a cliché crime movie as it displays a multidimensional killer; one that is knowledgeable and cunning--necessary qualities to deceive the whole public. It's thrilling throughout and the upbeat tempo ensures there's never a dull moment. I was quite surprised with this movie. I've always been a fan of Eastwood's films and this is no different. With great acting across the board and an even better storyline to match, Dirty Harry will surely entertain.

"Dirty Harry" is one of the iconic movies of the 1970s but it seems to have fallen by the cinematic wayside a bit. Sure, everyone knows it was one of Clint Eastwood's signature roles, about a tough but effective San Francisco cop who asks "Do you feel lucky, punk?" but for such a widely known movie, it isn't a cable staple, it's not an essential for DVD libraries. It's one of those movies everyone knows of but not a great many younger viewers actually bother to see. Is it getting a fair rap?The movie has its moments. As the movie starts, Eastwood's Harry Callahan is trying to mind his own business and have a sandwich but is forced to stop a team of bank robbers. This epic scene evokes the image of Eastwood's classic Man with No Name as he walks through the smokey urban canyon, huge gun drawn, fearlessly doing battle against long odds, and coming out with a mere scratch.I think the main problem with the movie is its core plot pitting Harry against a pure-evil maniac serial killer terrorizing San Francisco. The killer is played well enough but it's just so cartoonish a role that it's hard to take the movie too seriously, and considering the gritty, hard message the movie presents, it's a real problem that the villain is a cliché. The movie's message is that criminals can run rampant because of the 1960s civil rights restrictions to cop's ability torture suspect's for information, or having to get warrants before breaking into suspect's houses, and these sorts of restrictions where why there was so much crime. It's a message that might have had some populist appeal in 1971 but it comes off as pretty kooky 40 years later.Dirty Harry isn't a bad movie, but it's clear that it's dated. It's not as exciting as action movies of the 1980s, there have been much better detective movies, and its message is a tad naive and outdated.
