It's clear to me why this is a movie everyone has heard of but not a lot of people see anymore. Still, it's worth seeing... but it's not a must-see movie.

Review title: Dark, hard-hitting, sadistic and brutal, and yet... perfect
Review_body: *this may contain a slight spoiler*Who could forget the classic Clint Eastwood lines: "Do you feel lucky, punk?" Well, no-one; and that's why they're all the more fantastic today. To hear about a truly historic movie moment is one thing; but to actually hear it, feel it, breathe it? That's just different ballpark. Harry Callaghan is a homicide detective. He's a tough, uncompromising guy, almost darkly comically; I swear the bloke could go through several different emotions: happy, sad, angry or confused, without having the audience a clue what he actually is. He speaks up, yet keeps to himself; it truly is a testimony to how perfectly and toughly the script was written. So when a sadistic psychopath is loose killing innocent victims in San Fransico, who else could be assigned to the case? It really is an amazing feature to see how his emotions do in fact change, slowly, as the case turns from your average run-of-the-mill homicide case to an obsessive and impassioned literal fight to bring down the biggest threat in the city, at any costs. Hardhitting, brilliantly acted, and, well, fantastic, this is not your standard snip-cut police action movie like Die Hard or Lethal Weapon. This is serious, intricate, thoroughly well done work, that should appreciated by all. 10 out of 10

Review title: Inspector Eastwood behind a destructive and cat and mouse mystery
Review_body: Firstly, Eastwood's portrayal as the cool headed and smooth inspector who screams out with badassery. Delivering one of the most iconic and righteous quotes in history.The full continual tense and suspenseful atmosphere is heavily built on from start to finish, a foreboding sense of fear and mystery is also tied deep within.Finally, the ending. Eastwood once again carries his arrogant, cool, chilled persona and rightfully earns his place as the most badass man to grace Hollywood. Delivering his signature line and then throwing off his Inspector page knowing he's superior and the justice system is corrupt.

This is as close to perfect as a movie about a police chasing criminals gets. The plot is good, manages to fill the whole movie without any dull "cannon fodder" bad guy sidekicks. Harry and the killer has several confrontations without killing each other, and it only gets better by that. The killer gets away to plan his next sick move.I tend to believe that one quantity that affects the quality of action movies is the number of bad guys, especially number of kills. Fewer is better. More bad guys means less time on understanding each. This movie focuses on a single lunatic, and win a lot by that. Later Dirty Harry movies has more bad guys, but they add little or nothing, they are more or less paper thin sidekicks that are done away with with a quick bang.Casting is also just great. Many movies, not least new ones, have so bad casting that it takes an effort to tell characters apart. Not here. All leading characters are razor sharp and also doing their job flawlessly. Even some small parts (Albert Popwell, had parts in all 4 Dirty Harry movies) are impressing.And to add the last spice, the movie has a great one-liner, used with perfection, so good that Dirty Harry 2 opened with it.I find very little that I don't like. Police movies are not all that interesting as a theme, tend to land around 4-7 for me. Not this. Great stuff.

Review title: ''Justice in your own hands'' never seemed so entertaining.
Review_body: Since many Oscars have gone in the past years to movies that have a leftist political subtext (that's not a bad thing tbh, but I've just grown a bit tired of them), I wanted to see a movie whose message and subtext leans towards right, a movie with a perspective that I haven't really thought about that much.I still think it's not ok to ''take justice in your own hands'' and become just like Dirty Harry, but man... we all need this kind of escapism sometimes. This thought that you - and not some institutions controlled by some snobbish politicians and demagogues - can decide what's wrong and right and act in this way is a short pleasure that you can't allow yourself in real life but have part of through fiction. Of course, even murderers have a tad of humanity left in them and they shouldn't be humiliated or downtrodden and most of them aren't psychopaths but rather victims of the failure of society to care about them, to educate them. But just for this time let's forgot about this and see how ''the hero'' beats the s*** out of the bad guy.It's also the second movie I see that casts Clint Eastwood after Million Dollar Baby, but this time much younger. Great cinematography, some memorable lines and a good action movies, maybe a bit old but still very good.An 8,7 out of 10 from me.

I first saw Dirty Harry round about the same time the fourth film 'Sudden Impact' was released, which was either 1983 or 1984. This film is perfect.This is THE film that gave Clint Eastwood his signature role and movie immortality. This film is to cop thrillers what Star Wars is to sci-fi, like all great movies there are many moments and images that stay in the mind long after you have seen the picture.Classic moments: The opening sequence, the rooftop Sniper called Scorpio taking aim at a young woman swimming on a skyscraper pool; just listen to Lalo Schfirin's haunting and murderous music scored in perfect timing to the movement of the two characters (her swimming, him aiming at her through his rifle lens). brilliant.2nd classic moment: Harry running around San Francisco with a yellow gym bag filled with $200,000, running from phone booth to phone booth on the instructions of the Sniper in order to save a young girl that the Sniper has kidnapped. The sequence comes to a head at Mount Davidson Park at a huge monument called 'The Cross' where Harry is almost kicked to death by a red ski-masked Scorpio, and Scorpio shows his true nature by changing his mind and letting the girl die of slow suffocation. When Harry finally catches him at the Kezar stadium, and tortures Scorpio i defy anybody to forget this moment a year after seeing it.The ending is simple good guy versus bad guy,which for future generations i will not type here for although Dirty Harry was released in 1971, for me personally, it is timeless and in the time to come those future generations will see this film and maybe, just maybe, they will know that for all your Bad Boys and Lethal weapons out there, nothing will come close to the power of Clint Eastwood in Dirty Harry.

Extremely entertaining "Dirty Harry" is a very manipulative movie which leads us to cheer on a vigilante cop who's virtually breaking the law to bring in his murderer.Since Andy Robinson's portrayal doesn't reveal anything but an evil human being, it's so easy to side with Eastwood's vigilante cop. Especially when we know that the letter of the law in many cases protect the criminals more than their victims. Richard Donner must have been a fan of this film since there are so many similarities to "Lethal Weapon" which he made 16 years later. Clint Eastwood's "Harry Callaghan" and Mel Gibson's "Martin Riggs" could almost be the same guy.Clint Eastwood is magnificent in his part revealing the person underneath Harry's tough exterior.A great action-flick if you don't mind the politics.

I really mean what I say in the title of this.  This is probably my favorite movie of all time.  The acting is good, tha action scenes are good, and you never get bored during it.  Andrew Robinson stole the show as the psychotic killer Scorpio.  He is sometimes unintentionally hilarious like the scene when he gets stabbed in the leg and screams.  But I was still glad when Harry capped him at the end because of all the bad things he had done. Eastwood is a man of few words but his precence is felt throughout.  I recommend this movie to anyone who likes movie, especially action movies. 5/5

Review title: Watch this trendsetter(of the 'loose canon' cops)
Review_body: Ambivalent opinion ! The plot and the characters, in the first place, aren't notable enough to make an impression(probably I'm unfair writing this in 2015 about 1971 movie), Eastwood's acting limitations surface several times during the movie. But given the era of the movie, the plot is certainly realistic and innovative - urban crime, remnants of racism, the lame mindset of the law, the dangers and the frustration dealt by daredevil officers and the 'loose cannon' concept force the viewer to be uncomfortable and ponder over the the underbelly of the otherwise 'dream cities'. While I still rate 'Die Hard''s 'McClane' as the best 'dirty cop', Dirty Harry' probably was the trendsetter for which it should be given the due credit ...

Harry Callaghan is a tough, streetwise San Francisco cop whom they call Dirty Harry. In this action classic, you'll see why.A rooftop sniper calling himself Scorpio has killed twice and holds the city ransom with the threat of killing again. Harry will nail him... one way or another - no matter what the "system" prescribes. This film stars: Clint Eastwood, Andy Robinson & Harry GuardinoDirty Harry a 1971 police thriller directed by Don Siegel who worked with Eastwood when he directed Coogan's bluff. This film is known as Clint Eastwood's best film. Not in my opinion although it is a very good film it is not my favourite. I do recommend this film to all Clint Eastwood fans and if you watch it enjoy.****/***** Very Good

This film is a classic.People love it because Harry dishes out his own brand of justice.All the BLEEDING Hearts out there don't watch.Harry is glad to shoot any crook that comes along.Scorpio is a vile villain.He enjoys killing people.He will meet his match in the streets of San Fransico Harry Callahan.The ending is still a surprise to viewers.Music and acting are first rate.

Review title: The best of the Dirty Harry series of films.
Review_body: A well directed and filmed cop film with a difference. After watching this film, it's no surprise that it spawned so many films of this genre. Don Siegel's handling of the film is excellent, with the clash between Harry's contempt for Scorpio reaching an interesting climax. A script & characters that you could believe may or could exist in real life.

Review title: The Best Cop Movie of All Time
Review_body: Dirty Harry. The title itself suggests a high level of veracity and a bad-ass performance from the title character. By God does this movie deliver in more ways than one. Before Lethal Weapon, Clint Eastwood was the ultimate cop. San Francisco Police Inspector Harry Callahan is our cop fully realized. A man who cares about protecting the victims and getting the job done, before bureaucrats and the law try to stop him. Eastwood and director/mentor Don Siegel give us one of the best movies ever made, especially considering what genre it's in. It also ranks high for me because I am a native San Franciscan, so seeing my city for a story such as this is breathtaking.The story entails Harry's cat-and-mouse game between him and the psychotic killer known only as "Scorpio." Scorpio is based on the infamous Bay Area Zodiac Killer, who killed and kidnapped people for ransom from City Hall, but unlike the movie, he was never seen or identified. The actor who plays Scorpio, Andy Robinson, plays what is one of, if not my number one, greatest villains of all time. He looks like a choir-boy (as Siegel had intended) and he plays him with absolute menace and sadism. He is truly terrifying and looks like he just has fun playing the SFPD (especially Harry) like fools when he throws a loop in the procedures. He is flawless all the way to the end, and I believe Robinson was unfairly snubbed for a Best Supporting Actor nomination.We also begin to see one of the biggest ideas in the movie. During this game, Harry gains an even greater enemy, the suits from City Hall and even the higher-ups in the Police Hall of Justice. Because of Harry's methods of bringing Scorpio to justice. The issue of victims rights vs. the rights of the criminals and often how criminals are unfairly released because of the red tape and laws that would allow it are presented extremely well in this movie and also annoys us when we realize there are such laws on the books.With that in mind, when Harry takes it upon himself to apply the law as he sees it, it leads to some of the greatest scenes in Hollywood history. He is able to stop a bank and deliver his signature line "Do you feel lucky punk?" all while chewing on a hot dog on his lunch break. The other is on the field of the hallowed Kezar Stadium as Harry shoot Scorpio down and tortures the information of the girls whereabouts out of him. When I said that Harry is our idea of a cop fully realized, these scenes are what solidifies that statement. He does what we want to do to sickos like Scorpio, and shows us how people like this should be treated, instead of worrying if we will get in trouble. Is the torture scene violent? Yes it is. But that violence is what gets people talking about this movie, much like what Quentin Tarantino seeks for his movies, a debate about the ideas presented in the movies.This is one of my favorite movies of all time. The acting is perfect, the writing is phenomenal, Don Siegel is at his finest here. San Francisco looks spectacular and gives the perfect backdrop for such a story. If you are feeling lucky, check out the movie and judge for yourselves.

Review title: You gotta ask yourself one question...
Review_body: Hard as nails San Francisco cop, Harry Callahan known as "Dirty Harry" by his fellow peers for his perchance at handling any dirty situation that comes his way. Along with Magnum Smith and Wesson, Harry must stop a serial psychopath known as The Scorpio Killer, whose viciousness is only matched by Harry's ruthlessness in this deadly game of cat and mouse.The first in a series of films, in what quintessentially is the bread and butter of several action films to follow it. Eastwood is perfect in his representation of Harry and what is considered the standard bearer for all cop films and action heroes to come. Dark, gritty and raw in its very core, nothing about this film is soft or even considered politically correct in today's standards. The story is original for its time as well as the pacing of this film. The dialog is spectacular and the viewer will become engrossed in this film from its very opening minuets to its climactic conclusion. It's hard to not become engrossed or the very least fond of Eastwood's portrayal as he fits the role of the character perfectly, and with his signature catch phrase that has now etched its way into popular culture, Dirty Harry is a film that not only resonates but has held up to the test of time. A film that eventually will spawn 4 sequels, dark, moody and specially violent for its time, this film is a must see for any fans of pure cinema and one can't consider themselves a movie buff without viewing what is now considered a classic not only for the genre but in cinematic history.

A number of respected reviewers have been highly critical of this movie over the years which has surprised me a little as it contains some good elements. True, it is, perhaps, a touch too violent which isn't really my scene. But, Clint Eastwood and Andy Robinson are excellent in their respective roles.I'm a sucker for anything that's been filmed in San Francisco (always a picturesque backdrop)and Lalo Schifrin's music is so evocative of the era. Eastwood was never better than he was in this picture as the thoroughly unlikeable maverick cop Harry Callaghan who believes that justice should be dispensed instantly and decisively right on the streets without the formality of a court case.Robinson also did a sterling job as "Scorpio", the psychotic sniper who terrorizes the 'City by the Bay' from the top of downtown buildings. Although there are moments when Callaghan's capacity for cruelty makes Scorpio look like a rank amateur.For my money, it's still one of Eastwood's best performances. Clint will never be remembered for having one of the most animated personalities in the history of Hollywood. But when it came to delivering his own, unique brand of cynical and ultra cool vindictiveness he rarely failed to come through.

Review title: Row row row your boat. Come on sing!
Review_body: This film is a marvel from the bravura opening sequence with the sniper on the roof followed by Harry locating the rifle shell, to the iconic moment when he casts his badge in the lake. All held together by an outstanding Shifrin score. The opening is a great example of effective storytelling during a title sequence. Andy Robinson is a great psychopath as he seems completely believable and the film features great moments like him getting a bus load of children to sing nursery rhymes. Very uncomfortable, as is the stadium scene which has an incredible helicopter shot in it where the camera keeps on pulling out until the stadium is lost in the San Francisco fog. A wonderful film with a great star that seems to get better and better on repeated viewing. Siegel did a great job with this one. It also contains great dialogue that is highly quotable.

Early 1970s Hollywood saw the rise of vigilante films, which portrayed cops and citizens who were discontented by the state of crime in America and took up arms without a go-ahead from the police. In 1971, director Don Siegel and western star Clint Eastwood made 'Dirty Harry,' widely viewed as the definitive crime film of its time. While not entirely about vigilantism, 'Dirty Harry' is probably the best example of films that depict a justice system fixated on the rights of criminals when American cities are becoming overrun with felons who pay no heed to the law.'Dirty Harry' focuses on the deeds of Scorpio, a sniveling, obnoxious madman played by Andrew Robinson. Scorpio takes fun in placing all of San Francisco under siege by killing civilians from rooftops and threatening additional deaths if the city fails to pay a huge ransom. After some coddling by the police, Scorpio decides to kidnap a young girl whom he rapes and hides underground with limited oxygen. The police immediately turn to Harry Callahan (Eastwood), an inspector who is frowned upon for his rough-and-ready ways but tolerated since there are few 'dirty' assignments he won't take on. Callahan, already disillusioned by his superiors, is pushed even further to the limit in tracking down Scorpio and the missing teenager. With help from his new partner Gonzalez (Reni Santoni) and hanger-on Frank DiGiorgio (John Mitchum), Harry manages to capture Scorpio, only to see him walk free after the prosecution drops all charges on grounds of illegal search and seizure. Which leads, of course, to a hostage crisis that no sane person could imagineWhile the sentiments of 'Dirty Harry' may now seem quaint, the film still asks important questions about a middle ground between rights of innocent people and the accused. Callahan is depicted as a police officer who wants the American justice system to work, but finds himself at odds when trying to defend San Francisco against a ruthless lunatic. Harry sees law and order disintegrating at the hands of people like Scorpio, who are beyond reason and must be stopped at all costs. Callahan dishes out his personal brand of justice as expected, but the film ends rather bleakly, his vigilante-type deeds being just another indication of a society gone mad.Despite its controversy, 'Dirty Harry' had tremendous impact on the crime genre, leading to four sequels and influencing movies such as 'Death Wish,' 'Lipstick,' '10 to Midnight,' and the Abel Ferrara thriller 'Ms. .45.' A large portion of Dirty Harry's success is owed to Eastwood, whose rugged style of acting in the Leone westerns can be seen here. Eastwood's portrayal is balanced, with none of his speech or physical action wandering into excess. In fact, his acting is at times so understated that Harry comes across as a humorous and somewhat likable man. Only the role of Scorpio calls for an over-the-top presence and this is pulled off masterfully by Andrew Robinson, who admitted to having no experience in reading film scripts. The supporting roles, including Gonzalez (Reni Santoni), San Francisco's mayor (John Vernon), and Lieutenant Bressler (Harry Guardino), are all played with honesty.The straightforward editing of Carl Pingitore ('Play Misty for Me,' 'Across 110th Street') is nicely paced, keeping the action sequences moving at a brisk clip while at times slowing things down to keep the film grounded in reality. 'Dirty Harry' maximizes the San Francisco locations with broad angles and overhead shots by cinematographer Bruce Surtees. Never do we feel that 'Dirty Harry' is taking place in a studio or at a secondary venue. Composer Lalo Schifrin is also in top form with his eerie score that combines synthesizers and a regular ensemble to background this funky, depraved urban landscape.Although its sequels never lived up to the original installment, 'Dirty Harry' became a solid movie franchise, lasting for five titles over a 17-year period. Anyone who has seen heavily-edited, full frame versions of 'Dirty Harry' on television will appreciate Warner Brothers' 2000 DVD release of the film, which comes packed with extras. The movie is presented in its original widescreen format with Dolby 5.1 surround sound; French 'dubbing' is included with subtitles in English, French, and Spanish. Disc extras include a short documentary made at the time of Dirty Harry's release; a new 30-minute program on the impact of Dirty Harry, hosted by Robert Urich; interview clips with several who were involved in the Dirty Harry series; and the theatrical trailer.'Dirty Harry' is in excellent condition, although there are occasional artifacts such as grain and speckling. Unfortunately, its Dolby enhancement is not the finest, putting too much emphasis on gunshots and Schifrin's music. Dialogue and background noise are comparably soft, while Callahan's magnum and Schifrin's bass flex come out throbbing at climactic moments. This is not necessarily a bad thing, although it seems geared to those interested just in action. The original documentary is an interesting look at how 'Dirty Harry' was sold to audiences with its controversial subject matter. WB's new program is well-made and deals with the influence of Harry, but could have explored the film's initial reception and the flack its makers had to live with. Overall, fans of Harry should be pleased and the disc will be of great help in creating a new legion of fans.*** out of 4Roving Reviewer - www.geocities.com/paul_johnr

Okay, this is one of those movies that everyone "has" to see, according to my family. Alright, I saw it yesterday. And...I didn't like it very much. I have grown up with different movies which use the same plot structure and settings. I was most offended by the nudity in the film. If you have kids, and you're like me, keep them away from this one. Mom saw it in the theater (when she was pregnant with me! Now I've dated myself) and didn't recall the nudity at all. Well, I sure do now. If you have seen any movies with "rogue" cops who do things their way, this is the mother of all those movies. If you can handle the fact that it seems cliché NOW, after so many movies have followed in its footsteps, then go for it. Just beware the content is more of NC-17 than R.

I saw this movie when it was first released to theaters. Recently it showed up on HD cable, on UHD, and I decided to watch it. I had forgotten what a cliché-riddled piece of garbage this movie really is. It is an insult to the intelligence, and there simply is no way that any half-intelligent human being could appreciate this movie. The crucial point in the story line is when the prosecuting attorney lectures Harry for having violated the murderous creep's civil rights. Because none of the evidence is deemed admissible in court, they have to release the creep, and it is all Harry's fault. This is all preposterous. There is no semblance to reality, although I am sure that many people do not understand this and believe that creeps are routinely allowed to walk free by sentimental liberals. This movie may in fact have a lot to do with the misinformed belief that many people have, that liberal judges and lawyers are always letting creeps walk free.This movie is pathetically bad. It has no redeeming qualities whatsoever. The acting is as horrible as the story, including the acting by Clint Eastwood. The fact that this movie was every popular at all, is a very sad commentary on our culture.

Clint Eastwood epitomized toughness for two decades, and his iconoclastic anti-hero persona is on full display in 1971's Dirty Harry, my personal all-time favorite movie. While criticized at the time for its violence, and a cop's disregard for individual rights and "right wing" theme, Dirty Harry was nonetheless appreciated by those tired of rampant crime and lawlessness in many of the nation's cities. A revolutionary film, "DH" illustrates the frustration felt by both the general public and those in law enforcement with a system that too often weighs in favor of the criminal rather than the victim. It is a theme that is just as relevant today, and Eastwood perfectly conveys this concept by waging a one man war against a criminal totally devoid of humanity or viewer sympathy.When a crazed killer terrorizes San Francisco, Detective "Dirty" Harry Callahan is assigned to the case. Fed up with red tape and ineffective "traditional" police procedures, Callahan pulls out all stops to nab the killer- disregarding Miranda and Escobito procedures which are the linchpin of our system of jurisprudence. Andrew Robinson's portrayal of killer "Scorpio" is indeed a tour de force- one of the screen's best ever villains that stands up 38 years later. His performance is even more remarkable given the knowledge that Robinson in real life is a softspoken, peace loving man with a disdain for guns. Fine support is offered by veteran actors Harry Guardino, John Vernon and John Larch, all staples of 60's and 70's television. Lalo Schifrin's creepy score fits the theme perfectly and Don Siegel's direction is excellent.Dirty Harry spurred four sequels and cemented Eastwood's reputation as a box office titan. One of the best movies of the 70's and an all-time classic.

Review title: A great action movie about an important political problem
Review_body: After 35 years I find it amazing, how misunderstood "Dirty Harry" is (the movie, not the character). I am left-wing, in my opinion the Clintons and Al Gore belong to moderate right. And I don't see any "fascism" in "Dirty Harry". I only see an important political problem, important 35 years ago and as important in our days - think of the Twin Towers assault.The idea of maximal freedom for the individual is very attractive. The snag is of course, that there are some evil human creatures around abusing this freedom. It is possible to close your eyes and not think about it of course. But if you are honest, you have to. The first thing "Dirty Harry" makes clear, is that liberals and socialists have to pay a price. I think civil rights are absolute, the idea to restrict them in favour of safety/security is wrong. In The Netherlands Pim Fortuyn and Theo van Gogh have paid with their lives, like the two girls killed by Scorpio.So is Harry Callahan right? Of course not. Don Siegel and Clint Eastwood portray him on purpose as a racist and a loose canon. Just ask a random police officer, if he wants to work with a guy like Callahan. The final scene is symbolic: Callahan does not belong in the police corps and he knows it. If you are right wing, ask yourself some questions. With your son or daughter in the bus - or even better: if that fishing kid were your son - would you want Callahan taking those risks? Here we see the only, but a big fault of the movie: when Callahan shoots Scorpio in the shoulder, the kid should have been killed. But I suppose, that would be too shocking. It would have been reality though.Harry Callahan himself also pays a high price. He has does not have a family life. Ask some policemen; the doubts of Gonzales' wife are very real. Callahan does not have friends. Also notice, that Callahan's sex life consists of peeping. One of his partners has been killed; the other is in hospital, where Gonzales ends as well.All you right wing people, can you honestly say, that it is worth taking these risks? Especially, when your family, friends and relatives are involved? Dirty Harry Callahan has a strong right wing political view. The movie has not. Essential is the scene, when Gonzales asks his superior, if it is right not to give Callahan a cover up. Lieutenant Bessler's answer is honest: he does not know. No matter your political views, you need blinkers to answer Gonzales' question.This is exactly, why "Dirty Harry" is superior to all the other tough cops movies, with types like Bronson, Gibson, Willis and Segal. "Dirty Harry" is unsettling, because it leaves the spectator without answers. This is underlined by the fact, that regular police surveillance in the movie saves two lives ...Two final remarks. Nobody has noticed the similarities between Scorpio and El Indio. I only mention them, as they are obvious. Andy Robinson is great, but I think Gian Maria Volonte even more frightening. I also find it amazing, that so many people think "Dirty Harry" violent. Please, do a body count and compare with hard boiled movies since 1980 until today. The fact is of course, that there are not that many victims. The good guys get hurt as well. Neither is there any beauty in the violent scenes. Violence is portrayed like it is in reality: nasty, dirty, painful. It is present, today even more than in 1971, and there is no good way to deal with it.

Review title: This movie is never given enough credit.
Review_body: This is in a sense the cinematic version of The Sweeney in tersm of the public perception of it. People seem to see it as another Bronson-style tough cop movie, yet it is so much more. This attitude is not helped byt he rather cheesy title and the let's face it, pretty dreadful sequels which became caricatures of themselves. Dirty Harry succeeds on every level with what it sets out to achieve. The music is amazing, especially in its exciting percussion and its incorporating of background effects. The camerawork is neat, and the selective use of violence (eg we don't see the dead boy, only Chico's reaction) shows you the care and seriousness put into this film. The football pitch scene is astounding, but for me, the single factor that lifts this movie into legendary status is the astounding performance of Andy Robinson as Scorpio. Cowardly, terrifying, human and yet emotionless, he is devoted to the part for every second and is a true portrait of the serial killer. A resounding scream of defiance to all the liberal attitudes of the sixties, Dirty Harry is a product of modern society, but unlike Death Wish the film doesn't want to stand up and celebrate him, only show how he is a necessary evil.

Eastwood made a first outing as Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callaghan in this Don Siegel film is nicely made in San Francisco back in the early 1970s. The film is all about the cop who takes the law into his own hands in this violent thriller remains one of the best. It's similar plot to Eastwood's film Coogan's Bluff made three years earlier when he too bends the rules.
The "reel length" begins with the inspector on the trail of a sadistic killer known under the name of "Scorpio" played by Andrew Robinson whom holds the city to ransom. The film is acceptable and funny with revealing plots and dialogues that gradually mount up. It's quite seedy too. There's also some slight degree of scenes of naked women but the film dates from the early 1970s and their peachiness was slightly different at the time.

The first sight the movie world got of inspector Harry Callaghan.Emerging through a door and proceeding to a rooftop swimming pool to inspect a murder victim shot from a nearby rooftop sniper.The introduction of a soon to be legend is made.A maniac sniper in San Francisco is killing randomly and at doing so at will with apparent will.He is demanding a ransom and dosen't care about killing more people indiscriminately in the interim period.The story evolves into a frantic game of cat and mouse between the sniper Scorpio and Harry.Ignoring the red tape and restrictions of his department Harry goes on a single man crusade determined to free the girl Scorpio has captured and to deliver some well needed justice to Scorpio The intense burning desire placed in the viewer for law and order created so well actually wishes Harry would would just be done with it and shot Scorpio dead.A whole good versus bad story with Harry being the avenger striking a blow for the average law abiding person.This quest puts Harry in vast conflict with his superiors.Harry obtaining the location of the girl having tortured Scorpio is told Scorpio cannot be held due to the lack of admissable evidence.Scorpios human rights have been breached much to Harry's disgust.The girl was dead all along.The percussion driven score is tailor made for Dirty Harry and during the action sequences defines the those sequences effectively The stand out moment for me is at the end.Harry totally sick of the system for putting criminals rights ahead of the victims launches his detectives badge into a river.A dramactic action from a man consumed by rage and feeling betrayed by the very law his job is to uphold A cinematic classic and a magnum shooting Clint Eastwood being propelled to superstar status

Review title: ..."You've got to ask yourself one question. Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya punk?"
Review_body: In the wake of a horrible serial killer named The Zodiac Killer was fear and terror that must have swallowed up the San Francisco area back in the late 60s. Perhaps the only good thing that came because of the horrors of a still unknown murderer was DIRTY HARRY. This was Hollywood's answer to a creep running around San Francisco killing innocent strangers.Clint Eastwood stars as Inspector Harry Callahan. To me the greatest cop in film history. He has his own way to get things done and his main and perhaps at times only priority is to catch the criminal. Harry really is bad ass and every role in which a cop has got attitude after this film takes its inspiration from this character. Not to mention in my opinion they kind of play second fiddle to Harry Callahan. Nobody could outdo what Eastwood did. We see him single-handedly stop burglars early in the film (a scene that I think was extremely well shot), which is also the first time we see his 44 Magnum in action.A psycho killer naming himself Scorpio (extremely well played by Andy Robinson) is going through the streets of San Francisco killing innocent people. Callahan has been assigned to the case and now spends the entire film trying to capture the killer. Robinson is so good in the role you should have a growing dislike towards his character right from the first scene.Really has a spectacular score from Lalo Schifrin who really wears the crown of "cop movie" scores as he scored BULLITT as well. Film really is an amazing mix of action, some great dialogue, humour, the early 70s in San Francisco and a really bad villain that needs to be stopped. Now, I have never visited San Francisco in my life, but that is one thing that this and the four sequels do is place you in San Francisco. I feel like I have visited the place after watching this movie. Much like BULLITT did as well. So, I just hope that to people that lived in those places at those times that it was a true feeling of San Francisco that you are receiving.Directed by Don Siegel and I do believe he was a great director. He and Eastwood teamed up for five movies together and all were really good. The others were COOGAN'S BLUFF, TWO MULES FOR SISTER SARA, THE BEGUILED and ESCAPE FROM ALCATRAZ. I think in this film there are some real beautiful shots like Harry standing with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background only to be revealed perhaps the ugliest shot in the film where the body of a victim is found.Also starring Harry Guardino as Lt. Bressler (Harry's boss), Reni Santoni as Inspector Gonzales (Harry's partner), John Mitchum (yes, that's Robert's brother) as Inspector De Giorgio and John Vernon as the mayor.If you have never seen it I say give it a shot if you like cop movies, just remember though it was made in 1971 and the city was also in the midst of perhaps its scariest time within its own history. Followed by four sequels (MAGNUM FORCE was next) all of which were really good, too.

_Dirty Harry_, along with _Death Wish_, is arguably the genesis of the modern vigilante/rough justice film which took up where the western took off.  The quest for vengeance continued on a new frontier - one of concrete and asphalt.In terms of images, emotions, gut reactions, _Dirty Harry_ is immensely powerful.  However, the morality and philosophy underpinning it is a hopeless muddle.  It's unusual that I lay the blame for anything at the feet of a film, but this movie, and the myriad imitations that have followed, have lodged vigilante morality deeply within popular culture, forming the basis for some very bad politics.It's not a bad flick for what it is, but it pays to view _Dirty Harry_ with a critical mind.

Review title: The Original Cop Vs Killer Thriller
Review_body: I first saw "Dirty Harry" back in the 1980s and I never get tired of watching it. It's so well-made that it's always a pleasure to watch. The script is one of the best Hollywood scripts ever and is filled with unforgettable characters, dialogue and action scenes.According to the Mayor of San Francisco (the great John Vernon), "there's a madman loose." The madman in question is a serial killer called Scorpio (he is also a paedophile, a rapist, a thief and an extortionist). Enter his opponent - unconventional cop Inspector Harry Callahan. From the start it's clear that Harry does things his way and resents authority, but he's a good cop and is let loose to hunt down Scorpio.It's in the conflict between Harry and Scorpio that the movie really comes into its own. They are equals in many ways, both are expert marksmen, both are control freaks and both enjoy sadistic games (Harry taunts suspects to go for their gun if they think he's out of bullets, a kind of variation on Russian Roulette. Scorpio kidnaps and buries a young girl and he runs Harry from one phone booth to another, if Harry misses one call, she dies. It turns out she was dead all along and Harry was wasting his time.) It could also be argued that Harry is as crazy as Scorpio, just look at his face when he steps on Scorpio's wounded leg in the football stadium to get him to confess the buried girl's whereabouts. Yet they are different in that they are on opposite sides of the law.Like Buffalo Bill in "The Silence of the Lambs," Scorpio is a fictionalized version of a real killer. The Zodiac Killer terrorized Northern California in the late 60s and was still at large when this movie came out (he has never been caught to this day). In one of his infamous taunting letters to the press, he claimed he would shoot a bus full of children. Although Zodiac never carried out that threat, Scorpio makes good on it in this movie by hijacking a school bus with children on board (while Scorpio never kills any of them, he has already killed a young black boy and raped and killed a young girl earlier in the film, so it's quite possible he could have harmed the kids had Harry not intervened).Andy Robinson has a field day playing Scorpio and he never really got a role that good again and it's a pity. Clint Eastwood suggested him to Don Siegel after seeing him in a stage play.John Wayne and Frank Sinatra were once in the running to play Harry Callahan - Wayne passed, Sinatra injured his hand. Thank God for that, Clint Eastwood was never better than in this and the role of Harry fits him like a glove (if you want to see what Wayne and Sinatra would have been like, check out "McQ" and "The First Deadly Sin" respectively.)The running gag throughout the movie is the reason why Callahan is called Dirty Harry. Another cop gives his theory that it's because Harry "hates everybody" and goes on to list all the racial slurs for those types of people. Harry himself, after stopping a suicidal jumper, explains that he's Dirty Harry because he gets "every sh*t job that comes along." Another possible explanation for Harry's nickname comes in two scenes where he voyeuristically spies on naked girls while tracking Scorpio (this voyeurism is another way he is like Scorpio, the movie begins with Scorpio watching a girl swimming in a rooftop pool through a telescopic sight and Harry even follows Scorpio to a strip joint later on).There is a fascinating example of how primitive criminal profiling was back in 1971. The chief of police makes a throwaway comment about how "sick guys" rob the same place many times. Today, forensics and profilers would be all over this case from the first murder and Harry's old-fashioned leg work would take a back seat.The subtext of Dirty Harry is really about the beginnings of Political Correctness and how old school cop Harry is unable and unwilling to conform to it. Harry would have begun his career as a cop when police brutality and racism were the norm and confessions were routinely beaten out of suspects. He gets a rude awakening when he tries that heavy-handed tactic on Scorpio and is berated by his superiors for it. It's clearly a shock for him; the other shock is that Scorpio goes free because Harry never got a warrant even though the dogs in the street know he's guilty as hell. It leads to the famous finale in which Harry, having cut through the bureaucracy and killed Scorpio, realizes he can no longer function as a cop in the system and throws his badge into the water. Box office success would dictate that Harry would get a replacement badge for four sequels. None of those movies could touch the original "Dirty Harry" (although the first half hour of "Sudden Impact" came close to matching it and gave us that other classic Harry line "Go ahead, make my day."). "Dirty Harry" remains an all-time classic nearly 40 years after its release and it remains my favorite Clint Eastwood movie and his best collaboration with director Don Siegel.

Don Siegel is part of a dead breed, the pulp filmmaker. They don't really exist anymore as film has become overrun with auteurs and popular films. Such directors like Quentin Tarantino, S. Craig Zahler, and to a lesser extent Eli Roth have attempted to replicate the effects of the 'pulp filmmaker' movement, to varying levels of success. The superhero films of now could be considered something of the 'pulp' age of films, but they don't quite capture the edge that the original pulp films had back in their day.Dirty Harry came out 5 years before Scorsese would put the vigilante sub-genre to rest with Taxi Driver, a complete deconstruction and tearing down of the genre, showing the vigilante as he would really be: a pitiful, alienated loner, lashing out at society and yet unable to find that the issues that he struggles with might be because of things that he can't control. No one was ever able to make a good vigilante film afterwards, and even some of the later Dirty Harry films struggled with the fallout from Taxi Driver, its impact and influence are inescapable.But Dirty Harry is interesting, as it doesn't quite lean into the more escapist, power fantasy aspects of Death Wish, it very much is a product of its time. It was made as the infamous Zodiac killings were being investigated, and coming after a decade where hope was smashed time and time again with the assassinations of figures like John F. Kennedy, his brother Robert, Malcolm X, and Martin Luther King Jr. It very much has the angst and anguish that came from the age before it. It has a raw anger and bitterness that can be felt throughout the film, and it's that hard edge that keeps it intriguing even after all of these years.Dirty Harry often goes back and forth from forcing you to confront harsher realities of the world to creating a new form of sensationalism with its more 'badass' moments. Clint Eastwood is iconic in the titular role: he's hard, cold, and steely in his conviction. He would be an ideal, yet he's hardly a man. He's a force of nature who seeks to avenge the wrongs of the world, and there is a certain escapism to it. But Siegel never seeks to glamorize Harry or anything that happens in this film. The violence and suspense built throughout the film are usually played to be horrific and intense, rather than something to be celebrated and cheered on. I was also surprised by the ponderous nature that it sometimes showcased, a trend that would be carried on in its post-Taxi Driver sequel Sudden Impact, though it was unfortunate to see the other films go on to become more like the other films of the vigilante genre.I'm surprised the so called 'cancel culture' of today hasn't gotten their hands on this film yet or the other ones that it followed, considering it's a film that teeters with celebrating police brutality and vigilantism, it often attracts reactionaries and boomers, who take the themes and ideas explored in the film and adapts them into their own short sighted ideologies, but I'm still surprised that in our more enlightened age that we haven't been asked to leave this film in the past and move forward, yet I don't think that it ever will. Its impact on popular culture is too great to be ignored.Dirty Harry is a neat contradiction, walking the line between entertainment and subversive artistic prowess. It's very much of the pulp film era, it's too interesting to be discarded, yet too of its time to be timeless.

I know, I know, this is a classic, some speeches from this movie have become an icon in pop culture. But I have to write an honest review for people who haven't seen it before, which means they will watch it in 2020 or later, so I have to use modern standards to judge. And from that point of view, this movie has nothing that we haven't seen before, nor does it present it in a better way. It's just an action film, with a slower pace than we are used to in this genre. It's enjoyable, but it hasn't aged well.

Even after 50 years, this is 10x better than the junk that Hollywood churns out now. Excellent story, excellent writing, excellent cast, excellent acting; Clint Eastwood, Harry Guardino, John Vernon and John Larch. And as the frosting....REAL composed music by Lalo Schifrin. Why can't they make movies like this now?

Review title: Dirty Harry: The Controversy. The Experience. The Art.
Review_body:
****Excellent***Good**Fair*PoorThere is a scene in Dirty Harry where he has shot Scorpio in a football field. Scorpio is there lying on the ground with is foot bleeding and instead of Clint Eastwood just picking him up and arresting him. He steps on his bloody foot like a roach. What director Don Siegel is displaying here is a realistic portrayal of what someone would do in this situation. Let's face it the man is a murderer so I don't understand why people were so offended by Dirty Harry's action. Dirty Harry is the film responsible with turning Clint Eastwood into a mega superstar. It is a great film because it shows how repugnant violence is in society and how the hero and criminal share more in common then you think.
RATING: 4 STAR"I know what you're thinking. Did he fire six shots or only five? Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement, I've kinda lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya punk?"

Review title: The first of a superb run of "Dirty Harrys."
Review_body: Frank Sinatra, John Wayne and Paul Newman were first choices for the role of Harry. Sinatra and Wayne were simply too old for the role and Newman was too slight and wouldn't have have portrayed the stoicism that Clint did. The role of Scorpio was supposed to be played by AUDIE MURPHY! Why not Woody Allen? Who made the above choices?Aside from those comments DIRTY HARRY was a magnificent blockbuster! It's what people want to see. They've had enough of the insanity spoken by the judge in the film.I want to congratulate the writers, Don Siegle the director, and all connected with this cinematic triumph. If anyone should have received an award, or at least a nomination, for best supporting actor it was Andy Robinson for his Scorpio. It was the most realistic playing of a psycho only equaled by Jessica Walter in "Play Misty for Me" also starring Eastwood. The only fault I find is Harry throwing his badge away at the end. Absolutely no reason for that. All the sequels prove this was one of the most appealing films.

Review title: Why isn't this movie in the top 250????
Review_body: Most actors are lucky if they have one moment that outlives their whole career. Clint Eastwood has had loads of these, but Dirty Harry still stands as his defining moment.Eastwood claimed in a documentary that the film struck a chord with people at that time because of the legal system being more concerned with the rights of the criminal than the victim. The audience feel Harry's frustration at not being able to see justice done. The legal system practises law, Harry Callahan and his 44 Magnum practise justice.The film is more famous for setting the standards for urban cop movies. It's fair to say that every screen cop since then owes some inspiration to Harry Callahan i.e no Martin Riggs, no Vincent Hanna. There wouldn't even be a Rambo. Between Eastwood, director Don Siegel and writers Harry Julian Fink and his wife, R.M Fink, they conjured up a cop that people looked up to and admired. It appears 'Dirty' Harry Callahan isn't going into obscurity ever.

The best of the Dirty Harry series of movies. Modelled on the real-life Zodiac Killer who terrorised San Francisco in the late '60's. Eastwood is very good as the laconic Harry but the movie is "stolen" by Andy Robinson who plays the part of Scorpio, one of the most vile and hateable evil scum you could ever encounter - how he missed out on a place in the top ten film vilians in that recent poll astounds me.  Sure it has its share of movie cliches but the movie flows at a good pace and the tension is maintained until the final climactic scene ".....you gotta ask yourself, do I feel lucky? Well do you....PUNK!?"

Review title: A perfectly timed film, for an audience who was fed up.
Review_body:
I just rewatched DIRTY HARRY for the umpteenth time. Still great. Since it is now 2020, here's a more recent take on it.
This movie was a result of the sixties. And yes, I was there. It's rather relevant today too, with all the rioting taking place but - we will, unfortunately, never see another Dirty Harry. Too truthful and therefore too 'triggering'. Our current establishment has gotten much too mamby-pamby for that.
Death Wish was another well-timed flick, for the same reason. Violence running over in the city and politicians and bureaucrats too afraid to do anything about it. Yep, that's 'Dirty Harry'. So, Harry does what needs to be done. He is what 'most' members of the audience, in 1971, wanted to see. Well placed and deserved ACTION. A comeuppance. The movie even plays upon the pathetic-ness of our courts by allowing Scorpio to 'walk' due to some ridiculous LEGAL technicality - AFTER he tells them where to find the dead girl. Our justice system. No different today. No justice for the law-abiding. But again people, in 1971, were fed up.
It's a satisfying film too in that the psycho gets it in the end. Way too many more modern films twist their ending. Since movies, to me, are supposed to be escapism, having a satisfying ending is important and having just invested two hours of my life into a film, I demand it. So, if the powers-that-be decide to 'subvert my expectations? Well, ... I will probably NEVER watch it again and will no doubt, share my displeasure with others. That is of course, THEIR choice. Mine, too. They need be prepared, though, for a rather dismal after-market for streaming and DVD sales cause I, at least, won't be buying it.
Give it a watch, while you can, if you like well-placed action and mild violence. When compared to today? Yes, it's mild.

Review title: Benchmark for cop thrillers of the seventies.
Review_body: Clint Eastwood is one of the very few actors who can be regarded as the one who is the epitome of numerous genre's. He first made his mark in Spaghetti western's playing characters who were enigmatic loners with a haunting past which is barely revealed, but was his motivating factor for dealing harshly with outlaws who preyed on the defenseless. The 'Man with no name' had little to say - he did it all with handguns used with deadly precision and his icy coolness unsettled his opponents. Eastwood has definitely surpassed John Wayne as the cowboy people most remember when westerns are mentioned. Then fortuitously he landed the role of 'Dirty Harry' after Frank Sinatra was forced to drop out. Although the man who 'did it my way' was a shrewd choice for the lead role, one doubts whether he could have claimed the character as his own the way Eastwood did. Now Eastwood defined another genre - the action genre.Harry Callahan is a man who believes in his heavy handed brand of justice. A tragic past drives him - his wive's death at the hand of a drunk driver - and once again Eastwood is the lone gunman defending the weak. He cuts out his individuality in the police force with his long hair and big gun. The gun is his means to rid the streets of those who harm others. He has no regard for 'outlaws' who operate outside of society's morals and will taunt them with sarcastic remarks. His taunts took on a more serious tone at the climax when he challenged Scorpio to go for his gun. We are in no doubt that he hates this man and that he wants to clear the streets of him permanately. Harry's flaws are also outside of what is acceptable and proper. His drive to deal with the bad guys endangers others and he has little time for inexperienced partners who may get in the way of his own brand of justice. But the audience forgives him for these flaws as he vigilante style rids society of it's menace. His one - liners are not frivolous and create tension as he challenges the bad guys. Harry thus exudes immense power since his is doing what others wish they could do. He becomes the hero of those who may be disheartened with the system and deals out just rewards. Harry is frustrated by 'gutless' superiors who he regards are the ones who are putting society at risk. They regard him as a loose cannon, but serves a use when it comes to dangerous jobs. In the end he gives up on the system and walks away from it. Thus Harry is the 'man with no name' in the 70's. We can see that Eastwood found the transition very natural.Scorpio is ultimate example of scum to Harry. He will harm anyone who gets in his way and kills to gain a sense of power. Money is not the compelling factor in his deadly game, but the power to challenge authority and take lives. He even pays for a severe beating so that he could frame Harry. Undoubtably he wants to make society pay for his misfortunes. The fact that no motivating factors are revealed makes him seem more cold - blooded and psychotic. His maniacal laughs and twisted expressions create a man who is separate from us and only exists for one thing - to kill. Andy Robinson's contribution to making this movie the benchmark that it became, must almost sit beside that of Eastwood's. He creates a character that seems so inheritly evil, Dirty Harry became Clean Harry after killing him. Performances like this were lacking in the sequel, although that is not the only reason they pale by comparison.Although Harry will be incomparable to the police of that time, the movie starts off with a tribute to them. They get away with it since Eastwood makes Harry the cop the audience wants to see. Of note here is the fact that some police departments produced training videos showing scenes from 'Dirty Harry' and using them as an example of 'how not to it'. This, as proven by the numerous sequels, was never to prove a deterrant for audience's as Harry blasted his '44 across our screens. He was also to influence action heroes of the future, most notably Arnold Schwarznegger.To have not watched this movie, is to have missed a genre defining one. Not only did Eastwood claim title to another unforgettable character, action thrillers were influenced by him. His one - liners are a huge part of our action heroes of today. The anti - hero (Harry), although not started by this movie, become the benchmark against which audiences were to measure others. It may seem dated, but complex characters and great acting will always provide entertainment through the generations.

This movie might appear simple, plain, predictable or even childish to some fan art movie fans, but for me it's a true force! What it may lack in plot, it gains in superb acting, directing, script ("The most powerful handgun in the world" line is just unforgettable, it's instant classic), and some decent social and philosophical ideas. It gives us a perspective on the way of maintaining order in the society which gradually decays at the astronomic speed. In 70s, it might have been an artistic impression, now it's close to reality. This is truly the best part ever played by Clint Eastwood, and agruably one of the best and most stylish action movies ever. I give it 9/10.

Review title: You just don't see movies like this anymore.
Review_body: I can honestly say, this is one of my favorite movies of all time. It's quite simple from a plot-perspective point of view. But the acting and script is just spot on. You really get into the movie and root for Harry to catch the killer.It seems as if the script was written for Clint Eastwood. His acting made Dirty Harry truly come to life. The actor who played the killer was also fantastic, he played the role of a more twisted version of Alex DeLarge from "A Clockwork Orange"The director managed to capture the essence of what San Francisco was all about in the early 70's.You just don't see movies like this anymore.

I've heard of this movie since it was new. It came out about the same time as "The French Connection," a splendid movie with great acting, direction, cinematography, dialogue, story line and believability.I always assumed this was a great movie, based on its reputation.I was very misinformed.I watched it on television, through all the bad cinematography, errors and lapses in continuity, absurd plot, hopeless screenplay, but after the scene with the judge and the D.A. in the latter's office, that was it. It was way too stupid to put up with it any longer.I lived in San Francisco off and on from 1961 to 1982 and it didn't represent anything close to reality in criminal justice with which I was extremely familiar, during that period. It didn't even make any sense geographically, for instance with the bag man magically moving from one end of the city to the other in the absence of available transportation, and the same with the final bus scene.This debacle was inspired, if you could call it that, by the Zodiac killer, who murdered individuals and couples in San Francisco and all around California. He was never apprehended and his identity remains unknown. This was an opportunity for a great movie that was completely wasted.

Review title: A must watch movie. I'm sure you'll like it. And it you don't, I gotta ask you, "Well, do you feel lucky, Punk?" :D
Review_body: A provocatively taut thriller, this was the movie that gave Clint Eastwood a new identity, different from Leone's typical spaghetti westerns... A simplistic crime thriller driven by the characters mainly and a fiercely strong protagonist who gets all the dirty and shitty jobs as a cop... Dirty Harry doesn't bother about rules... the only thing that matters to him is getting results and he successfully gets results in all situations so brilliantly... How he solves all the messy situations with verbal intimidation and a magnum .44! The movie gives us some of the coolest lines and dialogues in film history! And now I understand the similarity of the Zodiac Killer and the Scorpio Killer. It's interesting to know that this movie took "Zodiac Killer" just as a reference and Fincher actually narrated the whole "Zodiac Killer" story through his movie "Zodiac"... And now I understand the references to "Dirty Harry" used a lot of times in "Zodiac"... Both are brilliant movies...Eastwood is just so fantastic in whatever he does. With a strong performance, knock-out dialogues and super-cool attitude, he is bound to leave a mesmerizing effect. Andy Robinson is good as the main villain too, especially in the freak out scene with kids in the bus. Don Siegel has a remarkable eye for camera and minute details too, a few scenes like the one in the stadium, are brilliantly shot.Overall, a must watch movie. I'm sure you'll like it. And it you don't, I gotta ask you, "Well, do you feel lucky, Punk?" :D

In 1971 two movies were rivalling each other but would both go on to be cult classics. They were The French Connection and Dirty Harry. I thought The French Connection was absolutely terrible but Dirty Harry really blew me away. I seriously think it should be the pure classic of 1971, not The French Connection.Clint Eastwood plays his legendary signature role of Inspector Harry Callahan in the first of a series of five movies where he investigates a string of murders which leads on to a brilliant storyline. It has a few good action sequences too. But the most memorable part of the movie is Clint Eastwood's brilliant job as the conservative Inspector Harry Callahan whose character created the benchmark for many other similar movie roles. Eastwood may be well known when it comes to directing movies but when it comes to acting, it will be Harry Callahan for which he will be most remembered for.All the Dirty Harry movies are good but this first one is the best by far.

Review title: The epitome of an American action film that is overlooked
Review_body: Much has been discussed about this 1971 cop thriller for the last four decades since its release. Many filmmakers and actors of the action film genre have paid their tribute to this film and its titular character; preserving its four decade long legacy. However, the film is overlooked for its visual storytelling. Not that it uses any groundbreaking shots and editing techniques, but the film has the precise aesthetic quality of a low budget thriller. One of the most memorable shots in the film was the overhead zoom out of Harry torturing the Scorpio killer in the foggy Kezar Stadium with Lalo Schifrin's jazzy score effectively conveying the bleak tone of the scene and shot. This kind of aesthetic detail in a low budget cop thriller (let alone an action film) doesn't get enough credit from film goers and critics. Another overlooked quality are the performances. Clint Eastwood effectively adapts his already established western hero persona in a contemporary setting. Andy Robinson's chilling performance (that certainly traumatized me when I first watched this film at the age of ten) as the Scorpio Killer paved the way for the hyperbolically insane villains that have become a staple in that film genre. The screenplay has the lean pacing of a thriller, but is cleverly written with dialog that is just as lean and to the point. Personally, the perfect American action film has the raw aesthetic quality, with a lean script, and naturally great performances. Dirty Harry fulfills those requirements successfully.

Very few stars from the golden age of television and film survived into the Reagan era the way that Clint Eastwood did. If you're looking for reasons, the answer is in "Dirty Harry" and its reactionary message of hatred for the counter-culture. Unlike the fine docudrama, "Helter Skelter," "Dirty Harry" doesn't go into character in any depth, preferring to create hateful paper thin stereotypes for the bigots in the audience, regardless of whether they hate left wingers, liberals or cops.Ironically, this exploitation film must have appealed very much to the unofficial censors in Washington, D.C. who later gave birth to the influential media lobbying groups which turned Hollywood into a propaganda organ of the political right wing with such movies as "Missing in Action" and "Rambo II." The miraculous success of Eastwood's career since this mediocre movie was made shows how adopting a right wing approach confers a competitive advantage in politically reactionary times. By the late 80's his movies were showing all the time on broadcast TV, but hardly anyone else who got started in the golden age received any air time at all. Because there were so many stars more talented than Eastwood who got started in the golden age around the same time -- Clint Walker, Tony Franciosa and Nick Adams, just to name a very few -- it's reasonable to wonder if there wasn't an anti-left wing black list in Hollywood and Washington beginning in the early 70's, which favored reactionaries like Eastwood over the more talented competition. Nonetheless, I'm sort of a reluctant fan. It's too late now, but instead of "Dirty Harry" I wish that Eastwood had appeared in a movie version of "A Cool Million," from the novel by Nathanael West -- a satire on the subject of homegrown American style right wing totalitarianism. The part of Lemuel Pitkin, the boneheaded leader of the buckskin shirted fascists, would have been perfect for him and a real challenge to his acting ability!

SYNOPSIS: A San Francisco Police Investigator hunts down a psychotic serial killer in the 1970s.CONCEPT IN RELATION TO THE VIEWER Sometimes you have to break the rules in order to do the right thing. Dealing with the endless red tape that comes from living and working in a bloated and spineless bureaucracy. Coming to terms with the frustrations that we all must face at some point in our lives.PROS AND CONS This film is iconic. It set the standard for the 'new' cop/buddy films that were to follow it like a stampede. Lethal Weapon, Die Hard, L.A. Confidential and a slew of others owe their origins to this film. This film solidified Clint Eastwood as a major presence in Hollywood.This is a film that we have all seen (probably numerous times). It has been a staple of television and cable for years. However, the version I watched on Laserdisc was the uncut original film that I don't believe is seen much these days. This film is easily censored and shortened in order to make more time for commercials and to fit into a 2 hour time slot. After watching this version, there were scenes that I don't recall having seen in the past. Scenes that don't add to the plot, but do flush out the character of Harry Callahan more and make him more complex than I remembered.In this original version, Harry has a lot of inner demons and is not a nice guy. He is bigoted in a very politically incorrect way. There are racial slurs and references to ethnic stereotypes all through the film. There is also a lot of casual nudity in the background which is something that censors and advertises eagerly cut out to get this film on public television.Along with "Bullitt" (Steve McQueen's police drama, also set in San Francisco), this film redefined the role of the police from angelic and efficient protector of the populace to the anti-hero where the rogue cop fights not only crime but his own department to get the job done.Several things stand out in this film. First of all is the wonderful melding of Lalo Schifrin's musical score with John Surtee's camera work. They bring an intimate sense of voyeurism and hip-ness to 1970 San Francisco. Going back to when I first saw this film, I have always been impressed by Scorpio (the serial killer in the film) played by Andrew Robinson. Even at the age of 10 I was curious why he didn't get an Oscar nomination. He scared the bejesus out of me and still does.As with anything successful (Rocky, Die Hard, Rambo), this film spawned 4 follow-up works all staring Clint Eastwood. The later films are somewhat curious after seeing the first film. At the end of "Dirty Harry", Harry Callahan, throws away his badge and as he has hinted all throughout the film, gives up his life as a police officer. Having disobeyed the police commissioner, the mayor and his supervisor, it seems unlikely that they would have kept him on the force. But then again, box office receipts are a powerful motivator.

Review title: A Great Start to a Long Series
Review_body: This is the first in Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry series. It set a new standard for action movies, in my opinion. It started a trend with a main character who operates just within or just outside the law, dispensing justice with hard-nosed action. The San Francisco scenes are excellent; the dialog is perfect; and Eastwood was great in this role. The action is very realistic, although we know that our laws would not allow it to really happen. The bad guy is so bad that we have no pity for him at all and are happy to see him die. The role was played to perfection by Andrew Robinson, who was new to movies, coming from the stage. I like all the Dirty Harry movies, and this one really set the stage for the series. I will watch it again often.

Dirty Harry is every cop thriller you've ever seen. The bad guys play dirty, so the cops have to play dirty. Gee, that's never been done before.I love Clint Eastwood as a stoic antihero, but he's a horrible cop. A cop that doesn't care is worse than a cop that cares too much. Eastwood's cop is boring and has hardly any character. What small bits of personal information we're fed have no place in the rest of the plot, thus feel out of place and excess.The writing is awful. It's unimaginative, unoriginal, and aimless. The story feels cooked up just to get Eastwood behind a gun again. It's barely held together by the search for the Scorpio killer, who is a boring antagonist and is in no way a match for Eastwood. Everything he does is predictable, which completely disarms him as a real threat.This movie is popular because everybody likes to see Clint Eastwood with a gun and an attitude. This is not to say he isn't good at what he does, but it isn't enough to save a bad movie, which Dirty Harry undoubtedly is.

Review title: THE best cop action thriller of all time.
Review_body: Here's a thriller that stays tight as a drum from start to finish. I've seen it a bunch of times and still love every frame. Clint Eastwood takes his unmatchable work from the '60s westerns and takes it to a whole new level here. This is the defining role for one of film's most iconic figures.The story boasts the most devastating setup and payoff you can possibly imagine. If you don't know what I'm talking about, you haven't seen the film and need to.A thriller is only as good as the villain and Andrew Robinson deserves full credit for rendering the most loathsome bad guy ever. You absolutely cannot wait to wring this character's neck! (But you'll have to...) It's a shame that Robinson wasn't more visible after making this film, because he really does great work here. If the subsequent Dirty Harry films are less worthy than the original, it is in no small part due to the lesser caliber of the villains.Flaws? I don't see any! (Maybe political correctness, but if you're looking for that here, well that's just sad.) This is the absolute peak for director Don Siegel, Clint and composer Lalo Schifrin. (If the performances don't put a chill down your spine, the score most definitely will!)I really can't imagine anyone ever making another thriller as exciting and satisfying as this one.

Review title: THE no nonsense zero tolerance cop thriller
Review_body: One of the most charismatic movies ever made. It's infuriated liberals ever since it premiered but that was one of its intentions. Well done for it, and it was partly inspired by factual cases where killers had their charges dropped after lawyers argued the accuseds' abuse and violation of legal rights by police. Eastwood plays a homicide inspector who is so sick of the legal system being played by defence lawyers he has decided to be judge himself, meaning trouble for any murderer he's chasing.What's surprised me reading about the making of it is how many big name star actors were approached for the role of Dirty Harry and turned it down in apparent disgust at the character and the tone of the film. Newman I could understand but not some of the others - Lee Marvin! Step up Clint Eastwood and walk into movie super stardom! And there isn't anyone who'd've done a better job of it. Wayne maybe in his day but his day had gone to do it credibly.Eastwood played the zero tolerance cop with relish and conviction and no shortage of style. From the half eaten hot dog to the pistol pointing wise cracking ending, the first shoot out scene, so blunt and direct and full of charisma delivered a picture into movie folk lore. Relentless from then on with really hard hitting scenes for 71, this would cause a stir in the movie industry after audiences loved it and wanted more. They got a lot more and not just from Dirty Harry, as there were many imitators after this iconic (sorry couldn't avoid it) movie.Eastwood was supremely charismatic and super cool in his portrayal, giving us one of the most memorable and quotable movie characters ever. But a special mention must go to Andy Robinson as the really disturbing killer who has nearly as much screen time as Eastwood and goes to town on his nutcase compulsive murderer, Scorpio. You'd probably question the Mayor not insisting Harry Callahan be taken off the case, considering he wanted to pay off Scorpio from the start but it's clear even Harry's superiors have more than an sneaky admiration for his no nonsense methods.Dirty Harry, the movie is a hard slapping crime thriller that still serves as an antidote to legal weakness and injustice and political correctness. I've watched it countless times and it just seems to get stronger with every passing decade. The film packs a punch on many levels, not least pure entertainment and should be on any serious top 250 list. The fact it isn't on this one is down to the same true villains of the movie, liberals.

Review title: You've got to ask yourself a question - Have you seen this film?
Review_body: Dirty Harry surely remains on of the most iconic films of all time, even if it's not the best. Clint Eastwood become an icon and achieved film immortality with his role as the dirtiest police officer in film history as he faces one of film's best villains in a race against time. 'Dirty' Harry Callahan is a San Francisco cop with a difference - he's warped, perhaps even psychotic. Because of that, the police tend to keep him reserved for the most diabolical cases where they need a man who will bend the rules to get the job done (hence 'Dirty' - every dirty job that comes his way). After the precision shooting of a woman, Dirty Harry is assigned to the case. He soon finds out that there is a serial killer on the loose, who wants money to stop killing. The serial killer, known as Scorpio (Andrew Robinson), is a psychopath who knows no pity or remorse. When the city doesn't pay, he starts killing. Dirty Harry knows that the man won't stop, but is hampered by a flawed law system. A girl is then kidnapped and supposedly buried alive, and Dirty Harry lets lost his own psychotic side - one that matches Scorpio's. There are many messages in this film about the law, police officers, killers. But at a basic level, this film asks a very good question - what happens if a child is buried alive, has 5 hours to live and you know who the kidnapper is? That's the basic question asked. Harry goes much further than the law allows him, which in turn raises questions about the flawed law system, but also about why the police would hire someone like Harry in the first place. Is he literally hired to clean up the law's mess, or failures? Does he represent a total failure in the law system?The acting in this film is second to none. Clint Eastwood is perfectly cast as the ruthless Dirty Harry, and gives one of his truly iconic performances. He is then matched by the exceptional Andrew Robinson, who acted Scorpio so well that he received death threats in real life - he creates a character that you absolutely hate beyond all reason. And the direction and action in turn matches the acting. Don Siegel's relentless, level-headed direction keeps the action grounded and realistic. And the shot where Harry is waiting on the bridge for Scorpio is one of the best in cinema. Overall, this film is very, very good and iconic. Sometimes, the message is lost in the violence, or it becomes muddled. But it's enough to make you question the law system, and whether it's effective or not. And it's also enough to question how anyone would respond in desperation.

To watch this film now is to take a peek back at a time when we weren't so conservative, or P.C, or concerned with things like 'racial stereotypes'. It's a breath of fresh air. Hugely influential, this film hasn't aged one bit. The music is distinctly 70's, yes, but it's very good. Easily the best film in the Dirty Harry series - the follow up suffered from very weak, 2 dimensional bad-guys and the progressively more boring sub-plot of Callaghan's continual clashing with his superiors. Detective Inspector Callaghan is a flawed man - a xenophobe, a voyeur and prone to going with his gut rather than obeying the rules. However, he was the first in a long line of flawed cop characters to be brought to life on the cinema screen so his character should be looked upon as a seminal touchstone in popular film culture. Mel Gibson's 'Martin Riggs' from the first Lethal Weapon film is a similar character, and probably the best successor to Callaghan, and it's interesting to note that the rooftop jumper scene in the first 'Lethal Weapon' owes much to the similar scene in 'Dirty Harry'. Of course, one of the reasons that this film is so great is because of the infectious malevolence of the villain 'Scorpio', played to the hilt, and then some, by Andy Robinson. All of the villains that followed in the Dirty Harry series paled by comparison and that's probably one of the big reasons why this is the best film in the series. A great film that stands the test of time.

9.2A lot of people don't like police officers. They see them as men and women who are abusing power. It is easy, in their eyes, to become a police officer and gain authority. While I agree that there are certainly a great number of police officers (and military men) who fall under this stereotype, there is still the fact that when things get shaky, the first person you want to see is a police officer.The character Dirty Harry, the protagonist in the film, is a very cliché character. In your fantasy, if you were a cop, would you be something like Dirty Harry? You most likely would. He's a man of action, he get's the job done, no matter how dirty it is.
